content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Once upon a time I'd happily recommend this. But last I checked the grind had almost doubled. Ignoring that, originally you only fought against ships of your own tier. Which was fine, the queues were only a minute long. Then suddenly they made it akin to WoT, where you can be paired up against ships of a higher tier.in WoT, irritating as it is as a lower tier tank you're still -somewhat- useful. Star Conflict? There's no real scouting mechanic. You are slower, weaker and significantly less durable than any ship a single tier higher than you. I distinctly recall firing everything I had at such an opponent, but his shields were able to regenerate faster than I could deal damage, even if he sat still. This is the equivalent of a tier 1 WoT tank going against a tier 5 (If it were a tier 1 and 2 ship in SC). As you might guess, this is horribly misbalanced and the T1 has no hope in hell of doing a dang thing.Again, it really pains me. The game itself was -good-, I enjoyed it. The grind increase was iffy but I could deal with it, but the botched tier matchmaking (Which evidently was an attempt to imitate other, similar, games, such as their own War Thunder, but without considering the fact that a T1 ship is utterly useless against a T2. Whereas in War Thunder a T1 plane is still capable against a T2) was what really killed Star Conflict for me.Mind you, this was ages ago, so they might have changed it back, or re-balanced each tier. In which case feel free to correct me.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This game is... uneven.Don't get me wrong, you can have fun - I've had fun and still find some enjoyment in it - but its not the most user-freindly.The main reason I cannot recommend it is because its not a game everyone could get into even if you like the type of game, and it easily turns away players with some of those uneven lines that make the gameplay frustrating at best.It is not so much a MMO as its a multiplayer space shooter with a lobby and instances matches. It makes for a really isolated gameplay feel where your interactions with players are largely limited to the matches you find yourself in unless you can strike up enough of a conversation with a few of the talkative types in chat.You play matches with wait times between how the matchmaker tries to balance teams. The game is largely divided between PvE and PvP play, with an increasingly unfair feeling PvP feel as the MM attempts to balance things. You'll often find what will feel like unbalanced matches where one side will effectively steamroll the other.At the core, its a fancy space shooter and that shows inside the PvE with the AI being horribly predictable and abuseable. It does lean to making some of the game fun with an ease of use, but can have stark contrasts with horrifyingly difficult spikes when overwhelmed or facing some of the sporatic Bosses that don't play the same rules - not that you won't learn how to handle them, but their contrasts can make some teams stumble and falter under the shift. It adds to a frustrating feel as the game collapses and players under the pressure of the shifting difficulty  may not be able to handle it. For those that can - its a thing of beauty and a kind of fun enjoyment, but it can be increasingly few and far between with much frustration with poor matches inbetween.It can lead to what seems to be a few players that lean on what can seem overpowered ships carrying a random PvE team, maybe abusing some AI glitches or bending the rules in a way to complete a mission instead of working as a team to complete it.That gameplay is sub-divided between ship "Tiers" that holds a varrying degree of 3 "Ranks" within it. Ranks 1-15 is split between the 5 Tiers, making the majority of the game further split in its playerbase. Rank 1-3 is Tier 1, Rank 2-6 is Tier 2, Rank 7-9 is Tier 3, Rank 10-12 is Tier 4, Rank 13-15 is Tier 5. The major downside of this is further reducing the playerbase making some game modes unpopular and feel unplayable. Tier 1, 2 & 3 are individual dificulties in PvP with Tier 4-5 being lumped together for the endgame content. The highest Rank ships in the tiers often dominate the matches, discouraging many of the ships from playing outside certain modes such as the Sector Conquest for Corporations (like Guild/Clans) for special perks. Even then you'll find Tier 4 largely not used inside PvP for its lower ranking compared to Tier 5.PvE now splits the game into Tier 1 "Beginner", Tier 2 & 3 clumped into "Easy" and Tiers 4 & 5 into "Hard". The difficulties are relative where the right preperations and a good team mix can still make the most of the match. However with the Tier split and generally lower player population the PvE is largely limited to two options unless you start up a premade team to do one. PvP remains largely random, but Tier 2 and 3 are easier to start with Tier 1 and 4 & 5 much slower, expecially during Conquest fighting times. Certain missions will feel harder or easier depending on what ships are used, and an unfair edge if felt with certain classes on many of them.There are 3 ship types of Interceptor, Fighter and Frigate that are split into 3 sub-classes; Interceptors of Recon, ECM, Covert Ops - Fighters like Gunships, Tacklers or Command - Frigates are Long-Range, Guard or Engineer. The sub-classes largely determine gameplay styles and certain ones can frequently dominate particular match types. Interceptors largely dominate PvP and Frigates own PvE in most modes. Certain game types benefit from a different ship, such as Capt vs Capt PvP having Frigates is good and some Bosses are easier to handle with Fighters or Interceptors in PvE. But outside that the game largely breaks down into its grinding feel.You buy ships, grind "Synergy" through use to level up and get the next Rank to progress. Its alot of rinse and repeat gameplay that can drag on easily. And by far that is the worst thing going for it. The combination of generally low population, isolated instances and sporatic player involvement beyond point and shoot makes the obvious grind a bit dull despite its fabulous looks.As I said, and don't get me wrong - its a good and fun game, but its not for everyone. Free to play is good to try it out, but I'm not placing bets on player retention.

												Now, I shouldn't need to point out how Pay to Win this game is... the reason is that the "DLC" gives you perm. boosts to credits and such... Paying money into this game gets you so far you could unlock every non gold ship within a few months than years on the weekends. If you don't like Pay to win I wouldn't recommend this to you.The grind for non-gold players isn't as bad as like world of tanks as getting to Rank 6+ ships isn't hard and farming PvE is easy with friends... There is no real challange here except in PvP where the mm in my eyes tries to balance teams with atleast one good player per team but this game you need to know what to do or your team loses even if that means you get less kills or less efficany which makes the goal of an objective lost... You don't really get rewarded for spoting for artillary or Long Range ships... If you don't have capturing on (if you get hit) you lose out on a lot of points for capture (which is very high for some reason)This game is addiciting but once you have other games to play than this one will be worthless... Invasion is horrible as getting around in larger ships is hard and since weapon balancing is off for this mode you will die and lose all the work you place into it except for some missions you do... In unsafe zones if you don't have someone to back you up or your not in a high tier ship you might as well forget getting anywhere profitable on it and do the normal PvE missions.The developer for this game is trying to make money ONLY and not make a fair and balanced game for all... I understand permium or items cosmetic to the game. World of Tanks does have Gold tanks but they are not very effective againist their tier except for a limited few.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Glorified grinding. Except it's not very glorious.Flight and combat is brain numbingly simple; all ships have the same weapon placements. They can shoot best in front and slightly above, decently to the sides and some slightly behind (frigates, cruisers, etc) and not below or behind. Everything feels and flies like a fighter so there s no feeling of flying a big, badass cruiser armed to the teeth.Extremely limited armaments; you get a main weapon and missiles. And maybe an offensive ability. There are no broadside cannons backed up by short range lasers, with a forward facing railgun for taking out large ships. Nay, none of these ships have any sort of diversity at a given moment, and the options for weapon mounts themselves are pretty limited. Missiles come in several flavors, from "stronger, get with paid-for (yeah, I did the match, 30 cents for a one game use set of missiles.) currency" to "I'm smart enough to only spend the grindable credits for this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t."As a result, there's no real strategy beyond deathballing with your team and simply being more accurate with your pew pews (and having higher tier ships and equipment, of course). Positioning does not matter beyond using asteriods to block missiles (I seemed to be the only one smart enough to do this in all of my matches.. lol)I was most interested in PvP but I quickly found that you don't face any players until you get rank 5 ships... easily several hours playtime to get barely there. So starting out, you get to fight nothing but not so smart bots. And then there's PvE and Co-Op with even more bots that are still not very smart, just more plentiful and calling upon greater pools of health and shields. Simply wonderful (awful). PvP was eventually reached and the experiece was only slightly better than playing with the bots. But bots actually fought for objectives.. so it could be arguably worse?Objective based games were terribly shallow. Typical "capture the beacon" or "deliver the bomb" sort of stuff. The only mode that was genuinely fun to play was one where one player from both teams would be randomly selected to be the Captain. As long as the Captain was alive, ships respawned. To win the match the enemy Captain had to be eliminated along with all other ships. The couple of matches I got to play this game mode were a good tug of war with all ships on offense ready to scramble back to protect the Captain at a moment's notice.Unfortuneately, the entire time I was never impressed with myself after killing 9 enemies in a row within a minute because it's easy. Skill makes no difference; all you need is a good mouse and the ability to track a little circle with it. Did I have fun? Meh. Only in one mode, after hours of grinding to get to where I could actually play against PEOPLE instead of STUPID BOTS.Are the mechanics solid?  Of course, the game is well designed but far too minimalistic.. overall the simplicity makes it lackluster.Was it pretty? Hell yeah. Very nice looking game, at least. It just doesn't have the gameplay to boot.Verdict: 4/10 only because Captain assassination halfway made up for the rest of the time I wasted on this game. At least it was free.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I am giving Star Conflict a thumbs down for two/3 reasons. However, those reasons might not bother you, and since its a free game, I highly encourage you to try it out for yourself, and make your own opinions.On the three main reasons I gave Star Conflict a thumbs down. The first reason, is being a new player sucks♥♥♥♥♥ Now, don't get me wrong, a brand new player shouldn't have an "optimized" character/ship, with all powerful stuff. I get that. But the AI is Insanely unfair. Just as an example, I was trying to fly a rank...I think it was a rank 6 ship (mid level ship). I was paired with someone who was flying a rank 12, so all the enemies were Double my level, and of course the AI has the best possible gear "purple". It actually was so bad I couldn't even drop an enemies shields below 80 percent, just because their ship was SO powerful compared to mine. So bad match making I guess, but in addition to that, for the most part, the "general" chat is ignored. Meaning, as a new player, if you have a bunch of questions, try to find a forum or clan that helps new players, because realistically, your not going to find help. Again, to use an example, I've been trying to get a single question answered for the last three days, and been completely ignored in general chat. Not exactly condusive to new players. And the final nail in the coffin for this general point, is want to be good? Better set yourself in to read about 4-5 guides, because this game does NOTHING to explain itself to the player. What's good, what's bad, and so on? Nothing. Point 2. Pay to.....suck? Now, I understand P2W games. I also understand how and why games sometimes choose to do this. And being completely honest, I usually take advantage of that. Because I have limited time I can actually sit and play games, but I like to play with friends, so typically I'll just put money into a game to "keep up" with them. Star Conflict? Not the case. Bought ships are actually WORSE in the end then regular ships, meaning your forced to grind, and grind, and grind, and grind, and grind, and grind, and grind.....Point 3. Now, not everyone is like this, but there are Toxic players in the pvp section of this game, but unlike most other games, these toxic types are usually the only ones to actually respond. So to summerize, Very unfriendly for new players, really bad grinding/rng/time consuming, and Toxic/aggressive players that go out of their way to target new players. Those are the three general points that overall ruined Star Conflict for me. But hey, like I said, its a free game, give it a shot and try it for yourself.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												This game's graphics are making, it's very well polished and can run even on less than decent laptops. It's optimized very well, its fun and even has open space. Why am I giving this a negative review then you're asking?No one in this game talks and anyone who does is in russian. There's aspects of this game that are absolutely destroyed lke the covert ops class being unable to do anything now with the amount of guards/destroyers there are, basically anything that's tankier can make the covert ops ship class useless. That's rather specific though, what the real issue is the amoutn of grind and pay to progress this game has. I don't mind pay to progress games myself, but this game has such a wall for crafting ships later on, getting synergy to level up ships, and getting credits that it's just tedious work and not pleasent. Open space while fun, is lifeless as well. I love exploring the depths of space but I see there's not a soul out there but the alien AI floating around.The game suffers a small community and whenever I google or look up anything regarding questions for this game, there's nothing. For example, the mistranslation ont he skill "reactor overload" and how to use covert ops ship. Even just basic things like skills available for different ships at different ranks, it just seems like this game has no community or support to make anything knowledgable. Speaking of that, there's so many options I had to turn on since the game didn't automatically have them on for me or show me how to get better. There's a huge learning curve that players have to warn and tell you about that the game doesn't tell you.... what sucks about that is that like I said, there's hardly a community here. There's also a form of credit in the game that of course is pushed for you to use for just about everything you can obtain in the game. You "CAN" obtain things at progress without spending a dime or ths credit, but it'll take you ages to get anything you want or enjoy.The chat system is also very lacking. There's no /r reply button so you literally have to click the name of the person you're whispering to reply back to them. This makes having a conversation very tedious and obnoxious to do mid battle too. This game just seems to make it's best effort to be unsocial with the censor system too. For all the cool things you see in this game that you want to do, there is a giant grind/gap behind it that will make your determintion to get there very insignificant. You want those big destroyer ships that look awesome? Have fun grinding the 6mil credits and materials to farm one as well as the synergy to get to a rank that has one. Open space battles look cool? That'd be nice if there was actually anyone there. So between the endless grind, the lack of community, and feeling that nobody cares about the game(community and devs both), I rate it down in hopes this game actually does get better. I really enjoyed it at first, then it became pain and not enjoyable for how much I have to do and work for. I understand earning ships and grinds in games, but this one makes it a little rediculous. If there was a larger community, or at least more than 1k plaers online at a time, I could see this game being very addictive and fun. Otherwise it's lonesome, boring, and grind heavy.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22
												I've played this for a while now and wanted to leave my thoughts. I've only played till tier 9. If you try the game yourself you'll soon figure out the goods about this game. A bunch of different PvE maps, quite a lot actually, then the skirmish PvP and PvE has some fun maps too, the matchmaking at this point is really balanced as far as I remember it. At tier 7 you can start exploring open space, so there's a lot to see. Also imo shooting, moving and general gameplay is really fun. The core game is great but there's a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t letting it down.First of the PvE skirmish/Co-op, player matchmaking seems to be 1-5 | 6-10 but the enemy AI spawns 1-3 | 4-6 | 7-9 | 10-12. If everyone in your team is tier 6 except for 1 guy who is tier 9, every enemy AI will spawn at 10-12 with some tier 8 destroyers. Which means a tier 6 ship can meet a tier 12 which will insta kill him. Even by tier 9 command, which is semi tanky, can get killed under 2 seconds by 1 guard only shooting his lasers. If it wasn't for this, and the fact that it's so easy to change, I'd not think this game mode is bad at all because the maps and game modes are fun imo. This mode has a lot of potential too. I do play quite some missions PvE, Interesting and fun at first, but it's static without variation (no random spawn location, or variables in what spawns, when or anything at all) and there's a few locations on some maps that makes it too easy. I noticed a quite new map though, it replaces the old level 1 map and moves the old map to level 3. The new map however is way too hard for newbies and should probably be a late map. The rest of the maps I've played are too easy for most part and you can do all maps with only 2 ships. This is because you 2 shot small ships with guns like the singularity one. Every map except the new level 1 map are all exactly as easy to play. No difficulty progression. (I've not played the last maps as I only played with tier 9 as highest.)Open world: Lots of open space with some rocks, more space rock and some broken buildings, some cool alien stuff, it's alright. What bothers me is that it feels unfinished, 1 area the mobs are really easy, the next you have giant alien ships that shoots giant balls at you but so far it's actually not much harder. Then next map you have the same giant aliens but this time they also have 1 scout. The thing is, the scout has more hp, shield, does more damage, and gives less points. Why tho? I will never know. PvP + summary: I can't recommend it. It's okay, at first but the more you progress, the less you wanna continue on the same maps over and over. PvP queues are very long compared to the rest so you might not play a lot of it. When it starts a game it's usually only 1-2 players in each team and because of this the rest is filled up with bots, imo it feels way less empty obviously, but it's kinda a bot game. It's a little fun to me, like the master of puppets 1v1, but like the other things, it gets dull after a while. Also seeing how expensive the dlcs are and people complaining about their tier 15's being useless against op stuff I wouldn't recommend anyone to put their money into the game because it's simply too expensive, maybe they start releasing cheaper content making more ppl buy it. Play if you like, but I can't recommend you to try it out because there's a lot of options out there that do a similar thing.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Ah what to say about Star Conflict. As you can see I have put some hours into the game. Until the most recent update that introduced Destroyers into the game it was relatively well balanced for those that took advantage of the F2P model against those that choose to pay for upgrades, various ships and what have you. Those days are over. This is now a complete P2W game (not the first and will not be the last). You have to have a lot of rare components in order to "build" a destroyer, let alone upgrade the modules and weaponry. If you pay you can of course do this far in advance of those who choose to stick with the F2P offering of the game.Overall I believe the game is (was) fun to play under the F2P model and still probably is if you are willing to put up the cash to keep up with the new class of ship. Otherwise, you will be fighting many losing battles against those who opened their wallets to have the better ships.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Horrible game for the solo player. Without a corporation with coordination and good teamwork, you have a 99% chance of losing every single match, whether PVP or PVE. I spent the last two days playing the game after re-installing it, and the balance hasnt changed at all. Coordinated PVP teams♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥randomly thrown together teams of solo players, PVE rounds that are nigh impossible to beat (After two days and 17 runs, I have yet to see the Special Ops mission even close to beaten), and constant encouragement to buy your way to the top of the game make this one of my least favorite space shooters out there.I only play this game when my other games are offline. An excellent game if you like staring at timers, watching other people play, and losing to superior forces repeatedly. Almost ZERO solo content, impossible to progress without team play or group work, and pointless to play if you are a solo player as even the top level ships can be easily popped by a small mob in the open world. Not a game for individual players. Barely a game for team players, as it gets harder to near impossible as you progress. Fun for the first few levels, then a waste of time.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22
												I've played this for a while now and wanted to leave my thoughts. I've only played till tier 9. If you try the game yourself you'll soon figure out the goods about this game. A bunch of different PvE maps, quite a lot actually, then the skirmish PvP and PvE has some fun maps too, the matchmaking at this point is really balanced as far as I remember it. At tier 7 you can start exploring open space, so there's a lot to see. Also imo shooting, moving and general gameplay is really fun. The core game is great but there's a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t letting it down.First of the PvE skirmish/Co-op, player matchmaking seems to be 1-5 | 6-10 but the enemy AI spawns 1-3 | 4-6 | 7-9 | 10-12. If everyone in your team is tier 6 except for 1 guy who is tier 9, every enemy AI will spawn at 10-12 with some tier 8 destroyers. Which means a tier 6 ship can meet a tier 12 which will insta kill him. Even by tier 9 command, which is semi tanky, can get killed under 2 seconds by 1 guard only shooting his lasers. If it wasn't for this, and the fact that it's so easy to change, I'd not think this game mode is bad at all because the maps and game modes are fun imo. This mode has a lot of potential too. I do play quite some missions PvE, Interesting and fun at first, but it's static without variation (no random spawn location, or variables in what spawns, when or anything at all) and there's a few locations on some maps that makes it too easy. I noticed a quite new map though, it replaces the old level 1 map and moves the old map to level 3. The new map however is way too hard for newbies and should probably be a late map. The rest of the maps I've played are too easy for most part and you can do all maps with only 2 ships. This is because you 2 shot small ships with guns like the singularity one. Every map except the new level 1 map are all exactly as easy to play. No difficulty progression. (I've not played the last maps as I only played with tier 9 as highest.)Open world: Lots of open space with some rocks, more space rock and some broken buildings, some cool alien stuff, it's alright. What bothers me is that it feels unfinished, 1 area the mobs are really easy, the next you have giant alien ships that shoots giant balls at you but so far it's actually not much harder. Then next map you have the same giant aliens but this time they also have 1 scout. The thing is, the scout has more hp, shield, does more damage, and gives less points. Why tho? I will never know. PvP + summary: I can't recommend it. It's okay, at first but the more you progress, the less you wanna continue on the same maps over and over. PvP queues are very long compared to the rest so you might not play a lot of it. When it starts a game it's usually only 1-2 players in each team and because of this the rest is filled up with bots, imo it feels way less empty obviously, but it's kinda a bot game. It's a little fun to me, like the master of puppets 1v1, but like the other things, it gets dull after a while. Also seeing how expensive the dlcs are and people complaining about their tier 15's being useless against op stuff I wouldn't recommend anyone to put their money into the game because it's simply too expensive, maybe they start releasing cheaper content making more ppl buy it. Play if you like, but I can't recommend you to try it out because there's a lot of options out there that do a similar thing.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Star Conflict, a Free to Play Massive Online Battle Arena game (as of 0.11.0 )(side note: I've no idea what I'm doing! I'm still a newbie in reviews, so I hope this is helpful to anyone thinking about playing this game)Before I start this off, the reason I DON'T recommend the game is purely because it is STILL in open beta. And, the way things are going, it is likely to stay that way for quite a long time, unfortunately.After wasting countless hours in front of a keyboard on it, I've come to realise five things:1) That the game punishes you for doing good.2) The issues with ship balance (more specifically Premium vs. Free).3) The game is addictive as all hell.4) Leveling is a lengthy process.5) Gameplay is amazing. Physics are thrown out the window.----------------------------------------------------------So not everything is bad, but let's expand on this, shall we...1) Punishing your victories.It does. For as long as you queue solo, the game punishes you in extreme ways. If you win one battle, you get pitted against harder and harder opponents (as it should be, in any ranked game). However, the problem comes with the fact that the game punishes you by teaming you up with pilots that are... Well, let's just call them "below standard". For a fair match to occur, you'd need equal amount of skill level (Skill Rating in this game), which does not happen. And, in that sense, the Matchmaker needs a LOT of work and tweaking. So, as long as you're flying in a coordinated squad, nothing bad will ever happen to you.2) P2W? P2L? P2GL?The P2W discussions are getting old, FAST, so let this be here to clarify it once and for all. THERE IS NO DIRECT P2W IN THIS GAME. What makes Premium ships overpowered is a deadly combination of ship bonuses, slot layout AND, most important of all, pilot skill. If you put two pilots of different skill rating in the same ship, not only will their fits be different, but so will their aiming skills, reactions and module timing. The opposite, however (Free ships more powerful than their Premium counterparts) also exists in the game, albeit in a large minority (I daresay 1:5 ratio for Free > Premium).3) Drug addicts!IT. IS. ADDICTING. Like smoking. Or any light/heavy drug in existence. You reach a point where you NEED to play it and can't avoid NOT playing it. When you are playing it, you curse yourself for still playing it because the Matchmaker doesn't give you a breather.4) Leveling all ships is a lengthy process without a paid License for bonus Synergy (required to progress in the game) and Credits (ships get ludicrously more expensive as you progress), but not horrible. If I remember correctly, it is a 20% bonus with License and the DLCs (all of them), provide another 25% to both Credits and Synergy. They might be worth it, if you're willing to spend the money on them.5) The gameplay is solid. The Physics are not. Commands are highly responsive and nigh-instant as long as your latency is low (<180) and it all happens in low orbit. Either that or the laws of physics don't apply, here, meaning the hard-sf fans will be disappointed by this game. There is a minor attrition and if you stop your thrusters and there is no inercia.So, in short:Upsides:> Incredibly fun to play.> F2P.> P2W jokes left and right.> Solid, quick response gameplay.Downsides:> Expert pilots in overpowered ships.> Matchmaker punishment.> Lengthy progression.> Balance issues that keep getting ignored.Solid 7/10 game, all things considered. The downsides aren't enough to bring the game down and it IS still in beta. Give the game a chance, you lose nothing but some hours and disk space, all things considered.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												The good news is the game's introduction. You create your account with one click, you pick one of three possible starting ships, and the first view you get immediately presents you with options that look fun and interesting to explore. Front and center is a (completely optional) tutorial, that can give you the basics in a couple of minutes. Or, if you like, you can just jump in and start discovering the game on your own. Absolutely brilliant.The bad news is that the core gameplay isn't satisfying. The rocket physics are 2'000 years out of date, with ships that decelerate while not burning fuel, that have top speeds, and whose momentum turns with the nose of the ship. There are way too many design decisions made plainly on the basis of game balance, with no thought given to verisimilitude.I think a lot of people might like this game. I didn't. Uninstalled it within an hour, never played it again.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Если играть часок вечером подпивас, то как контр-страйк в космосе все норм.Если играть с претензией на "прокачаться, построить корабли", то тут есть серьезные трудности.Прокачка до максимального уровня корабля займет гигантское количество времени, по сравнению с какой-нибудь 'обычной' MMORPG. Я несколько лет играл в WoW, там спокойно, без zardotstva, прокачиваешься до макс. уровня за месяц.Здесь, наверное, придется потратить год, играя по часу-два каждый вечер.Когда хочется сделать перерыв от командных боев (как PVE-миссий, так и PVP-сражений) и полетать в одиночку, придется столкнуться с большой силой мобов открытого мира. Т.е. "пофармить ресурсы, пострелять мобов" просто так не выйдет, слишком сильны.Поэтому, спустя несколько месяцев, я столкнулся с двумя моментами:1. Полетать в одного (в открытом мире), пофармить ресурсы, пострелять мобов -- слишком сложно;2. Прокачка на PVE-миссиях и PVP-сражениях очень медленная (даже если играть по 8-10 часов в день).Плюс, последние несколько месяцев, что я играю, заметна тенденция к уничтожению режима PVP (передаю привет человеку (на самом деле, не человеку), разрабатывающему алгоритмы матчмейкера).

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Alright lets start, we have a  ´´massive multiplayer online´´ [media.tenor.co] space game where you fight and fight and fight. Ok, that is cool for those who like pvp. The things were good until Destroyers Update. All i saw in 2016 was Premium ships, premium ships, destroyers, premium ships, sector conquest, premium ships. The game now have p2w system, where you can buy ships that are better than the Secret/Special Project Ships, that was supposed to be the best ships in the game and you can only have them from the craft system, that is a sh##.Are you one of those guys that dont see the p2w? Ok, Brokk and Phoenix are Premium ships that have better support modules that the Octopus, and to get the Phoenix you need to do pvp/pve/coop missions with rank 8 ships only and then test your luck getting the loot after the battle, if you get 450 of them, you get the ship, or you can just pay. The Brokk, same thing to get the ship parts but costs 600 parts, and you can just pay again. And the octopus you ask? Well, now octopus is just another engi ship in the game.The game was good about 1 year ago, but now its only missions to get big ships that you can just pay too, then go in a battle with your big ships and destroy each other, or just go into pve mission or waste your time trying to get the minerals to build some sh## in Open Space.Im not saying the game is bad, its just worse than 1 year ago, and of course p2w.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												I've played Star Conflict extensively during the Open Beta, then in Sporadic but long bouts for another two years afterwards, being active in the forum in the beginning, observing changes, giving input, being ignored-----.Now then.You can essentially tackle the entire  game in two ways:You can either get premium ships, equipment, a guild spot and a freaking battleship, spending all your lollars on the way, OR you can despair over it, grind out your sorry♥♥♥♥♥ having to make do with savagely inferior equipment most of the time, like I did....At least I became a rather decent dogifghter that way.You can either move to Russia, learn russian while you're at it -for the guild spot, I mean- and, ALLEGEDLY, get at least a handful of games with short waiting times and no disconnects.OR you can despair over it, Wondering what on earth has you getting 10+ Minute wait times, 15 disconnects and seemingly scheduled server timeouts despite your state-of-the-art fiber-wire internet connection (4k porn? puh-lease...), like I did....At least I got to see the last 30 seconds of the match, though usually my absence caused my team to lose.You can either join one of the slim handful of dev-lobbying (also Russian) guilds (Sorry, "Corporations".) by throwing money at them so they can enlarge their D's (I'M TALKING ABOUT DREADNOUGHTS YOU PERVERT!)OR you can go solo, despairing over it, since that way it's fun-less, grindy goodness will make itself even more apparent, like I did....At least I got to feel like one of those silent, lone-wolf-space-mercenary types. So edgy.You can either realize it for the MMO that it is, just overlooking the garishly generic lore, look, quest system, UI, music, voice acting, OR you can despair over it, offering free voiceclips, music, writing, essentially all the love the devs kinda don't have the stomach to put into their Moneycow, like I And many others did....At least I had some fun times and conversations with people all over the globe.You can either keep holding onto it because at the core, it has really good, fluent and intense gameplay, awesome ship designs and an interesting faction/Loyalty system (IF ONLY ALL THE REST WOULDN'T TARNISH IT) and there isn't all that much quite like it out thereOR you can stop despairing over it, get a better PC or something, play some old X-Wing, go out there and find a Spaceship fighter that has the same kinda touch to it's system,like I'm going to do now....At least I can say that I really tried.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												It might be fun in the beginning, but it will all change the moment you get a Rank 6 ship, and you continue playing...- The grind is real, and has been increased with several "updates" over this year.- Destroyers have pretty much destroyed the game since their introduction. Missions for example were "balanced" towards destroyers, ignoring the fact, that many players don't have one.- While the daily tasks for Rank 14 destroyers are now PvP only, the number of destroyers per PvP battle has been limited with a recent patch.- The advertisement here on Steam is misleading, the game is clearly focused on PvP.- PvE is pretty much dead now, unless you find a Corp. that carries you through the daily grind of PvE tasks.- Updates and even events (time limited...) have the sole purposs of pressuring players into spending money on bundles.- Loot from the "trophy search", "open space" and even those lottery container bundles is random.- Reasonable critique and suggestions get ignored at best, silenced through banns at worst.- Forum Mods. on Steam and on the official forums bend the rules as they see fit.- And most positive reviews in here appear to be... odd.- It looks like there're more positive recent reviews then actual players in the game.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												This game had so much potential in it's beginning, and usually brought some pretty good updates, it's community was active and generally decent people, and developers didn't have a negative relationship with players.  Now, where we are now is where we have been for about a year now: In terms of updates, it's 1 step forward 3 steps back - we're made to believe that something cool is coming, or something good is coming, and sometimes it does, but usually updates that follow are either 1) ignoring problems with previous updates 2) fixing "problems" that never existed 3) Creating fixes for problems that actually then create worse problems 4) Make it more Pay-to-Win 5) add new useless, bad, or pay-to-win features/items.I can no longer say that I still play it for the game, rather I only play it because of the bonds I've forged with many of the pilots in my corporation, and I don't want to leave that.  I wouldn't recommend that anyone new wastes their time with this game.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												Okay... 130+ hours was seriously enough for me to get sick of this game.-First up, The fun ends at rank 6... after that it's just loads and LOADS of grinding.-Extremely Pay 2 Win/Pay 2 Advance... bundles are a cool feature but please let the people buy them for something else than Premium currency, or make them as daily rewards so the grind actually feels rewarding and not repetative af.-Open Space sucks, no joke... it just sucks... Credits located in asteroids? That's pure BS... or and did I mention you actually need to buy a special scanner to dishern where are the credits and where are the mats? Well I hope you have about 20$ laying around somewhere cause you can't get it anywhere else.-The new module upgrade system... Blagh! If grinding didn't seem bad enough then you haven't got the true taste of the new upgrade system... Last month it was following a pattern of to upgrade first you use normal currency, then vouchers (which you used get from repeatable assignments that respawn in 30 minutes) and then Iridium which could have been gotten from purple module kits... Now it has become like it's own exp... ohh and did I mention that you only get 1200 'module exp' per win and only 600 per loss? For beginners it would be an awesome experience but when you get to rank 9... ohh boy god bless your soul cause you will grind your butt off leveling one module out of 12!-Destroyer materials are hard to get... Okay... I can't stress myself enough how happy I felt when I found out that you could get Destroyer materials from PvE/PvP loot drops and all you need is a max leveled ship. No poblem I grinded my way to get a max lvl Crusader to start doing the Fire Support PvE mission, played 20 missions in one day... No freaking ore! Just like that! Nothing! The drop rate for it is so freaking low that in order to get a rank 8 destroyer you will need like... 3 months of non-stop playing, 24/7 without any breaks for sleep, food or toilet to get it from scratch... Ohh and you need about 320 ore pieces to get the destroyer structures... so yeah... rest in pieces your life.Suggestions; Make the game less grindy!! No seriously you turned away many people because you made it so impposibly to grind that others would rather play on some other game, Raising the drop rates for materials would be nice and get rid of credits in asteroids! This is not funny. Create a better Daily bundle system, no not the one where you come in after the reset and get a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ container, I mean YOU select which bundles to grind, like for example a Xeno-specialist bundle or something else that you want and go into missions to complete the task for that said bundle, maybe even make that you can only grind three bundles per day.Return the old module upgrade system... seriously, I don't want to spend my entire day leveling one module.All in all... the game is for you if you are a fan of salt and hellish grinding but if you are looking for a good game to play that doesn't involve grinding your the skin off your fingers, then don't play it.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												I've had some fun playing this game for a 'few' hours and have reached rank 13/15 recently.But now the grinding for new ships/parts became too annoying for me.This is partly due to some - in my opinion - bad game design decisions:-Your ships are disabled for a long duration when you leave a battle AND-Matchmaking quite often results in unbalanced teams AND-Spawn Camping is neither forbidden nor discouraged by an effective spawn protection. (There is one that is disabled as soon as you fire a shot, which will be your last one if half of the enemy team is firing at you.)Just to be clear: I rarely leave games but it is definitely NOT fun if you are killed within 1-10 seconds after waiting 30 seconds for respawn.-Since I received positive "Karma" by killing lots of Aliens in "Open Space" I've noticed a tendency to suddenly explode soon after entering "Open Space" because there has been a group of "negative Karma"-guys waiting for targets to spawn. - spawn police npcs seem to be helpless A variation of this is when you finally found some useful ressources during asteroid mining. (aka. "the galaxy wide easter egg hunt" ;-))-Late game ships require a huge amount of work to get. (I'm not even talking about maxing everything...)-Voice chat with team mates has to be activated via the settings menu but I'm not even sure if it works because I have yet to receive an answer...I only have limitted time that I could use to play this game and I decided to do something else now.That does not mean that you won't be happy with it but you should be warned about the things I mentioned. If you are not willing to spend/"waste" a lot of time into this game you might be disappointed.I'd like to thank the developer to include Linux support. It ran quite nicely.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Star Conflict has done most things well. This game has:-A pretty good soundtrack(it's more situational than memorable, but that's not necessarily a bad thing)-Smooth, easy-to-use controls-Creative maps-Great visuals that run incredibly well even on integrated graphics-A TON of ships and upgrades(the upgrade tree is similar to "World of Tanks")However, one thing is preventing me from being able to enjoying this game fully, or even be able to give a proper rating. I downloaded this game with great wishes to pla pvp primarily. Little did I know that in order to decrease waiting times, players get thrown into battle against the AI(remember, this is in pvp, not pve or skirmish). This is a great idea in concept, but within the 6.6 hours I've played at the time of this review, I've only played REAL pvp in two matches. Not only have I won every battle against the AI, the fact that I'm not getting to do pvp is preventing me from completing certain achievements, which I WANT to complete so I can move on and complete more to get more in-game credits. The fact that I have started matches with 6 players against 6 bots makes this even more of a frustration since I have fought many battles with just 2 players and 2 bots. Why can't the matches just be 3v3 instead of 6 players vs. 6 bots?I give star conflict a 4/5 only because of the "pvp issue" and a UI that can sometimes get on my nerves due to a lack of information. If anyone has played and liked "Metalstorm"(I know it's at least been on iOS) then I highly suggest downloading Star Conflict. It's basically a Sci-Fi metalstorm with the upgrade tree from World of Tanks.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												After playing for quite some time this is my reason for giving it a negative review, But unfortinately the Positives out weigh the Negatives (Reviews Wise) What the game does: On a Positive Note - Game despite being made as a space sime in 2011 - 2012 is by far the best looking game for that period of time- The Game has an Aracde feel to it. - Theres 3 factions and each faction has 3 main roles and 3 side roles, the total amount of ships is up to 163 i believe. The Federation is your Future Military Faction while the Empire retains an Old Military look, Jerhico is an Advanced Faction consisting of Multiple Royal Families Jerhico was also Exiled From earth. What the Game does: on a negative Note - To Construct say a destroyer you'll need X amount of resources, To get the reasources you need you need to go to the sector corrisponding to your ships rank, and Pray to god that you don't get attacked by Biomorph Hunters. - BIOMORPHS: Are an Alien Entity that roam in Open Space, they move in groups of 1, 2, Or 5, depending on the type, in higher tier sectors there will be lots and are very difficult to kill on your own, many have requested in the past to have the amount of Biomorphs reduced.-The Grinding factor isn't as bad from rank/Tier 1-6 anything after that starts getting quite grindy 7-10 can be pretty bad but once you hit you hit 11-15 its unbearable.  - Pay To Win? Yes and No, Premium Ships can provide personal Bonuses but you can also find parts for certain perium ships I.E.  Archelon, and you'll need 200 ship parts to get it. But its not as easy as one may think, per match you only get 1 ship part, so 1 ship part per match, you'd have to play 200 matches back to back to get said ship.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1
												The best I can say about the game...I used to love it.Combat was simple, yet fun, and it felt satisfying to activate a shield moments before getting hit with a missile that has the capacity to destroy your ship. Paying was optional. Sure, you could get some ships and skip progression of you paid, but you could do the same as a F2P player, it'd just take time. I felt like I was actually progressing as I got new ships, and getting new weapons/abilities.Then, a new ship type was introduced."Destroyers" (thanks to Phoenix for correcting me)In short, they were extremely powerful, but required quite a bit of work to do, OR you could fork over some cash, and get one instantly. (And, yes, they have been nerfed, but with a good engineer, the enemy is screwed)I haven't played in a while, but watched others play. Seems as though there are RNG "crates" to get new ships and items, but you need to pay to get them.All in all, used to be good, used to love it, then it turned into what most free to play games are...Pay to Win.Edit:Ok. I tried the game again, and, I have to say that the gameplay is still great, and I have a blast flying my little interceptor around, dodging other people's attacks. Although, I can still see the big pay to win factor, as I was being easily destroyed by people in ships that you could only obtain through real cash (I.E. "dlc"). Try it if you want, it's like most free to play games, but I don't, personally, think it's worth the cash.

Posted: August 21, 2016
												If you have played Endless Sky, this game is for you, but this game does have its drawbacks too. Sure, the game has a nice PvP/PvE system, but there should really be some solo tasks as well as an expansive ability to upgrade or even build your own ships from the ground up. One of the nicer features is being able to collect loot, but what good is that loot for other than selling it or letting it collect until you get a certain rank to be able to use it, and even then not be able to use it period? The authors should really do some revisions to make this game both have a better crafting system and to allow some single player battles against ships of your own class with difficulty settings that can offer more perks for challenging levels and ranks higher than your own.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												I recomend this game, and yet there are parts I'm not thrilled with. At it's core, Star Conflict, is a really fun and exciting space combat game. It's one of those games, that you'll keep coming back to, because it's just that fun. It's well put together, engaging, and the controls are easy to learn and master. It's one of those free to play games, that makes me want to kick the dev a few bucks, so they'll keep making more games, and updates to this one. I find the open space area, to be fun to explore, and I enjoy the missions. It does a great job at player emmersion.  That being said....there are some issues. I find that the leveling system isn't fair. Instead of earning experience for completing missions and winning battles for one of the three fractions. You level up by buying ships. Said ships only become available by leveling up the previous ships on the ladder. This requires synergy, an arbitary experience point system, that is mostly allocated to a single ship. There is free synergy that isn't bound to a specfic ship, but the amount of free synergy that you earn is a pittence compared to the ship specfic synergy. As you move up the synergy scale, the amount of synergy you need to level up grows at a staggering rate. Often bumping up by 5-10 thousand synergy. Not only that, but the open space area only opens at level 6. That area offers the most opurtunites to earn synergy and gather curency. You can transfer synergy from fully leveled up ships, and from premium ships, but this costs standards. The primary curency that is mostly gathered from in game purcheses, or dlc packs. It is infrequently given out in game, so the only way to get large amounts of it, is to buy it. Also cosmetic options for your ships, are bought with standards, and can cost the equivalent of 2-3 real world dollars. They also are ship specific. Meaning for example, if I bought an American flag for one ship, it wouldn't be able to be used for another ship. Said flag cost 100 standards, about 1 US dollar. I know this is a small amount in relation, but it stacks up after awhile. The cosmetics needs to be purchasble through the regualr curency, not premuim. At the end of the day, I do recomend this game, but the negitives might be enough to keep someone from playing, which is a shame, because at it's core, Star Conflict is a blast to play. I give it a 7/10, A good game, but flawed.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												Despite the promising teasers and exciting premise of a proper space dogfighting experience, I feel Star Conflict falls short of delivering a flat out entertaining experience. There exists a double edged sword when it comes to offering a free to play title along with paid content. On one edge, you've got the semblance of a fully enjoyable well balanced title. Obversely, there is that nasty temptation of paying to bypass grinding or paying to compete with other paid players. Star Conflict is no stranger to this system, and offers the payment option quite often, as many times as it can. Whether this be through pop ups offering deals on standards, or through post match reminders along the lines of 'this is how much you COULD have earned if you were premium.' I may be biased towards the F2P format for games, but when it's that in your face, it gets quite frustrating.Admittedly, SC is not without it's fun. At it's core it's a very pretty, smooth running game. There is plenty of visual candy to keep your attention focused on combat. PvE is an excellent alternative to dodge the paid players in PvP, and is done well enough that it's not inherently obvious you're playing against bots. They mostly consist of strike type missions mixed with capturing points. This is one of the few redeeming features I see, aside from other basic, but desperately needed additions such as a daily log in bonus (after five days, a free player can get 24 hours of premium status). Honestly, PvP can be avoided altogether if one absolutely wanted to. You get a decent amount of credits in the beginning to buy a few ships, but I started to notice the ships were getting more and more expensive when climbing the level tree. The daily login bonus coupled with the PvE missions were keeping me afloat and able to pay for ammunition after every match, but any more ships, and I feel I would start getting credit starved. This is where the curve starts to kick in, and it becomes ever more tempting to buy into the game to continue your progress. Progression is choked further when attempting to sell ships and recover some credits for the next level ship; I received a quote of exactly 1 credit when attempting to sell my used gunship. Not sure if this is just because it's a low tier ship, or because you genuinely get no credits for used ships. Thus, you are forced back into the same PvE mission to grind for more credits.Due to how heavily insistent the game is on purchasing credits, I cannot recommend this game to any serious player. At most, a few hours of fun can be had from progressing a few levels and playing through several PvE matches. Heck, you may even play a few very one sided, poorly matched PvP matches against high tier players too. Play the game for a bit, get what fun you can out of it, and leave once it stops being fun. Just don't spend any money on it, and you can leave guilt free.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Star Conflict, a game where you can fight in PvP battles in teams, play as a squad to complete missions, fly in open space and collect resources, earn various currencies to gain access to upgrades for your equipment, compete in specially formatted Dreadnought battles for sectors and build your corporation to be the best it can be.For a game that can be entirely free to play, this game is a great game. If you wish to so invest, I recommend the Elite Pilot package and the Galaxy Explorer, which will give you three top range fighter ships as a straight up bundle and 35,000 galactic standards to have fun with. The game staff also put sales on for occasions and even do weekend deals, where you can play and gain extra for your work and investment into playing; in other words, the more you play, the more the game will help you.Only thing wrong with the game is the standard of bug testing. Recently heard problems with MacBook Air running OSX El Capitan, but I have been running this game on my 4 year old MacBook Pro for 3 years now and it's working absolutely fine (also on El Capitan). Few texture bugs, but will be resolved soon.8.6/10

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Great game. Great graphics. Great controls. Ruined by developers. Perpetual grind. After grinding for 2 years to get destroyers. Yes, that's right, 2 years of gameplay. They introduce these stupid alien ships. This is how it works: The ships require constant upgrading, which requires a super rare thing called xenocrystals. You need these to update your Alien ship. Unfortunately the cost of upgrading the alien ship is soo high in xeno crystals that you can't buy alien weapons. You're expected to purchase crates. Or the crystals. the crystals cost 35 quid. Yes that's right, 35 quid. They give you 2 upgrades, so the ship may be upgraded 1 rank. There are 15 ranks. When they have bled your wallet dry upgrading one ship. They then will introduce another 12-15 ships using the same system of upgrades. And those ships you spent years working for, and some people spent money on? All obsolete. They get blown out the sky by new alien ships. So you can't play the old game. You don't want to play the new game. If you do play the new game, you'll be locked into endless quests to keep up the status quo you don't want to work towards. Now here's the best bit of all. When you do succeed. They developers will introduce new ships that will obsolete the old, and all the time and gaming spent is lost. It's not fun anymore. All the time now people complain about games they play. It's relentlessly stressful and irritating. Right now, there's one ship that destroys everything. No other ships can touch it other than the rank 14 destroyers, you can't build anymore. So you got all these players playing the same ship. Destroying all the starters and people who hate the new alien ships. 120 plus ships with tactical advantage right now, have no advantage of merits anymore. It's just the people with the most alien ship always winning, over and over again. So what was the point of collecting hundreds of ships? The match making system is screwed too. You need to win battles to advance your ships. But you can't win battles, because as soon as you do, the game automatically handicaps you. They put you against an entire team of alien ships. Your entire team gets utterly slammed. There's nothing you can do. You can't advance. You're locked out of progression by the game. To advance now, you have to pay to win. People are so fed up with it, they are leaving the game. But when they leave the game, the game matchmaking has to be less selective about who is matched with whom. This means you can find a rank 10 interceptor only half upgraded, against rank 15 alien ships, and rank 14 discontinued destroyers. It doesn't stand a chance. Then when you die, you realise that it was one of the stupid no respawn levels, and that you should have telepathically know this before the game randomly decided on that mission then you could have selected 4 ships to line up. Now you're locked in a game for 15 minutes watching your team get wiped out against team ridley scott and the facehugger devision. And what can you do? Nothing whatsoever, except wait. Time you don't have. Wasted. You could be playing a game making it more interesting for other players. But you can't because you're locked in a battle you hate, and the game surprised you with. Time to uninstall. I'll reinstall next year when the alien ship nonsense is over.Developer greed is criminal if they just reduced the price of things to 10% of what it is now, i am sure people would buy. But they wont, so actually they end up making much less money. It's really really stupid. Curse the developers of this game. I despise sellouts. In the past I've bought DLCs. Because in the past this was a good game. I got them on discounts because they were priced too high even for fan support. Right now, I don't want to support it. They are ripping people off. When I see my mates getting ripped off, my wallet closes. ♥♥♥♥ the developers. I've got more money than sense right now, but that's not the issue. The issue here is principles, and the developers don't have any. And that's exactly what the developers have done. They've sold out. What a shame.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Although it says I currently only have ~4 hours of in-game time for Star Conflict, I've actually played for 22.5 days (540 hours) as of the time of this review, and just reinstalled it using the Steam client. Star Conflict is an arcade-style MMO space shooter game, offering PvP (team deathmatches, capture the beacon, etc.) and PvE (set missions, instanced "open space") game modes.Overall, I have enjoyed it and would recommend as a fun game, primarily for its PvP modes, but with caveats. This game is for people who like flying around in pew pew space fighter ships; it is NOT a macro/econ type game (e.g. EVE) on a vast scale. Playable maps are bound (but rather beautiful to play in IMO), and "open space" feels obviously instanced, i.e. it isn't truly "open space."PROS:- Fun arcade-style space shooter game (primarily PvP--again, IMO)- Multiple ship classes to choose from, build customization- Pew pew lasers, missiles- PvP modes are fast-paced- Free to play (F2P), with purchasable extras (game is not Pay to Win (P2W), IMO)CONS:- Small game population (queue times, matchmaker can be annoying)- Grind becomes rather evident- Underdeveloped econ system; no player tradingIn conclusion, it's a free game, and can potentially be a lot of fun. It does take a bit of time investment, but for someone who's looking for a space fighter game, this might be a good one to take a look at. GL HF!

												Beautiful, Exciting, and highly addicting. Definitely one of my favourite games. Easy to get into, but with plenty of story and tactics to learn. Every ship is highly customisable: Piloting a frigate? How about a tough, durable, and very well armed ship at the cost of speed? Both give you options to fly and shoot at will.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												If Star Conflict would have been a pvp only game or an arena only game I never would have tried it...but...it also has pve, missions in open space and enemies that stop you from traveling too far in what you might think is a good ship. I have ships up to level 8 now, some elite, and barely can do missions 2 gates out from the base. Theres a ton to see yet, when you are ready. I really think even at level 12 there will be lots to do. The game looks decent graphically, and the ships are nice to look at too with a wide range of weapons.Really wish there was first person piloting but oh well.Like most FTP games it has a shop and without it you will grind for a long time to get good ships. The new detroyers are only available if you build one, and that takes quite a while, so grinding is standard for many things, and ships level 8 or higher can cost a million or more. So you'll need a lot of time or cash to become really sucessful here, but it is fun, so how you do it is up to you.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												This game has its good sides and bad sides.First of all, the handling of the ship is absolutely perfect, there are a lot of games that could learn a thing or two about fluid controls from this game. The ships handling is fast, responsive, easy to learn, and will allow you to move your ship more or less any way you would want to.Second, the quality of the graphics is very high, I would even go as far as saying they are beautiful. The last space game that I played was freelancer, and this game totally blows freelancer out of the water when it comes to the graphics.Third, the overall layout is intuitive and easy to understand. You will have no problem at all figuring out where you go to get new weapons, or what you have to click to go do missions, everything is layed out in a simple but good looking interface.However, the game suffers from that DLC nonsense we have all seen time and time again, and has other problems too.The biggest problem for me, is how generic everything is, it has a serious lack of personality. While the graphics are beautiful, they are beautiful graphics of generic looking things. Generic space stations, generic ships, generic races/factions, generic everything.The whole game, feels like it was put together by highly competent and passionate developers, who were forced into doing things the way the suited business men wanted it done. Namely, DLC and stuff.To me, it feels like a game that was made to fit a business model, instead of a business model made to fit a game. In other words, I think the idea to make money from a space game came before the idea to make a space game with this one.The second biggest problem, is that if you want to go PVP, or PVE, you have to wait to join some seperate instance thing. This procedure can take as much as a minute or two, and it causes the game to feel fragmented. Personally, I would preffer a large open space to explore, rather than lots of seperate instances to load.Overall, considering how much choice there is out there, I would not recommend this game.Having said that, it is totally free to download and play, and you don't really have anything to lose. The file is a few gig, and there will be an update after, so maybe leave it downloading and installing over night, and give it a try the next morning.5/10 that could so easy be a 10/10 with some tweeking.

Since then, I'm 95%  sure that Gaijin's entire development team was murdered by robots and replaced by a belligerent artificial intelligence that only cares about squeezing money from the playerbase while trying to make Gaijin's once-majestic games as anti-fun as possible. Ranks 1-6 are still ok, if you don't mind grinding through the crummy tier 1 & 2 starter ships, but past that? Get ready to die. BTW, Gaijin's idea of "balance improvements" in the last patch was giving the new Rank 11 destroyers a black-hole gun that bypasses shields and rips apart smaller ships in seconds, and giving T3 bots maxed-out T5 ships with red-quality mods and +50% to firepower, shields, and hull strength. Yeah. As of patch 1.3.3, Star Conflict is still technically free to play, so if you want to help stick it to the 'bots by using up their server bandwidth without paying, then go for it - but for the love of god DO NOT SPEND ANY MONEY ON  THIS GAME. You WILL regret it in the long run.

												I played this game for nearly 1500 hours using game launcher and if don't believe me, check my achievements. There is no way you can get them in an hour or a day or even a week.Developers say it is a team game, but unfortunately it is not. In fact it punishes you for being in group with a friend, increasing your queue time dramatically. If there is no any other group to place against you, just forget about battle.Open space is very limited and boring. Randomly generated quests are basically 3 types: kill a thing or many things, protect the transport, fly to to another thing and activate/pickup it, and activating and picking it up is the same action to be honest. Some of daily quests there are too difficult for a single person, but you will never find anyone to help you because as said above, there is no reason to team up, unless you want to wait half a day to enter pvp battle.Want to give developers feedback or report a bug on their forum? Dont forget to add how great their game is, any negative feed back will be wiped out in minutes.I really want to recommend this game but i can't.

content:
Posted: January 12
												Star Conflict feels like the space game you always wanted to play at first. It has open space, variety of ships, some tactics, some looting, many elements of the genre are present in this game.And yet it's a bitter experience; that of an unfulfielled promise. Like an attractive looking candy that ends up tasting like♥♥♥♥♥♥Soon it won't really matter which ship you use, what matter is that you have level up your ship to its full potential. Soon tactics won't matter, what matters is that you get the lowest ping. The game physics has a terribly ping adverse behavior: ping > 380ms (not even THAT high) will send your ship wobbling uncontrollably. Soon it won't matter that you know how to pilot a ship, you'll be so over-dominated in even the most basic PvE missions, that it will require an hour of re-tries before you get your loot.The progress is so ridiculously slow past level 11, that it is not even worth attempting.Finally, the social aspect. Almost inexistant, for a multiplayer game.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Star Conflict is a nearly flawless (in my opinion) space combat simulator. The complexities and the fun of this space combat build slowly through the levels, starting from a very high standard and getting better from there. There is an adequate crafting minigame and some half-baked questing. Optimizing the ship is made up of several minigames taken collectively. Optimization in its several pieces makes up a good, fun minigame.      There are areas of the game in need of improvement, yet the game as a whole is certainly in the top ten percent of space simulators. This review makes the case that Star Conflict is easily THE BEST f2p space combat simulator. We will not dwell on the shortcomings here, because the idea here is that you should just enjoy the game as it is at any given time and mostly let the devs worry about how to improve it. Overall, this is a great game.     If you are very diligent in researching the reviews, you will find many reviews that say, "This game used to be great, but they ruined it." These people are trying to help you, and they are giving you their honest opinion. But they are limited in focus to the particular changes that annoyed them, and in my opinion most of them would admit they are not really reviewing the game as a whole.     Here is the real reason for all the "They ruined the game!" reviews: When the devs make something new, they want the community to step into the new material and try it out. Therefore, as it is in almost any game that has ongoing development, NEW STUFF IS ALWAYS OVERPOWERED. Once everyone has tried it, the devs scale it back into balance with the rest of the game. Some of the 'they ruined it' reviews are due to new stuff coming in overpowered, and some of these reviews are due to previously overpowered content finally being balanced with the rest of the game.     The game is living and evolving. This is a good thing! Your investment in this game will be rewarded with all kinds of new adventures, and the fun never stops. Yes, read all the reviews. But please understand the underlying reasons for the huge variety of reviews is a very good thing: a great game that grows and evolves over time. What are you waiting for?

												Smooth graphic engine, precision control over your ship & weapons, all packaged up with fun skirmish mode of gameplay. Although the game modes are limited at the moment, the core game is solid with plenty of ships & items to unlock or buy. Mechanics also implemented for character/faction progression which also in-turn adds more customisation options. The netcode is really good resulting in a positive multiplayer online experience. Is it a MMO .. No, are the DLCs good value .. No, but try it for free & buy some in-game credits for boosters .. the rest you can quickly earn in battle! If you are a fan of space sims, sci-fi or competitive gameplay check this out.If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												StarConflict was honest and skill-dependent 3d space arcade.With quite nice graphical part and high potential. New friends have been found, and some of best time spent playing.Due to greedy managing and questionable developers all positive sides degraded into awful matter.This is not simply a Pay2Win game. This is a Keep Paying 2 Win. (©Gizmo.mac)Greed is good. This is developer’s motto. Development process was simplified: Create new IMBA ship which will dominate the battlefield.Make it expensive and available for real money. Make grind to new ship long and painful.As soon as ordinary players get enough resources to get this dominating ship - nerf it, and roll out new IMBA.Even investing 600$ may only grant you domination for a month or two, then your precious ship will be nerfed to brick.You pay more, or die from another "happy customer" as everyone else.Nobody cares about player’s opinion. Player can be banned for little to no reason. But - if you invest enough money in game - your ban can be revoked, allowing you to scam, grief and cheat again.Forum ban can be gained just for having your own opinion, or not hailing developers.In-game chat ban can be gained just automatically - with no reason.Full account ban can be gained by cheating, or arguing with GM, or writing a negative Steam review.All bans can be revoked by writing a positive Steam review.Look at game time on positive reviews - how much players recently exceed game time of 100 hours? Targem just forges positive ratings by face accounts IMO.There is no control over GM's and CM's, with complete disrespect to players from their side.Example - Community manger calling me "scum" constantly on his stream, ended up treating to ban my whole team - because he was killed and we were clearly winning.Another example - league system discussion stream. Top corporation’s leaders present, decision was made that leagues will be in 8vs8 format.Leagues were started as 4vs4 - nobody cares about player’s opinion, even if they ask.For all years of the game existence I witnessed an ad less than five times.When the game was released on Steam - there were high online - for a month. Somehow people in charge wasn't aware that their servers already operated at peak power, and lots of new players just pushed the system to lag hell.No new servers were added, new players went elsewhere, and with maximum online of 600 I may get "Server under heavy load" message.Now, what will you get if you will try to play StarConflict now?Until you will reach Rank 4 ships - there will be a pale shadow of its former beauty and glory.Almost balanced, somewhat slow, with less options for modules but so nice.Progressing further will bring you into feeding frenzy of epic proportions. Unless you will invest A LOT in the game - you will be cannon fodder. Again and again, with progression slowed on purpose, hard caps on income unless by money investment and matchmaking weird enough to put you against ships 5 ranks higher than yours.Old days, when skill determined an outcome of the fight are gone. It's hard to overcome auto-aiming weapons, auto-healing enemy ships, and your team hiding under brown rocks whole match.Certain team compositions are unkillable on progression ships. Until you will farm or pay enough to get a counter-class ship yourself - you will be farmed. With little to no chance you will be stomped upon.If your stats become high - expect totally useless team as a boulder on your neck, have a happy time carrying these. And again. And again.And be prepared - some in-game activity can be accessed only through third-party site. There are no control about that site, but rewards and progression are counted on it. So pay no attention if there are shifts in final teams, or people not present in battles are rewarded.Latest addition - game items stockpile are limited now - so you can't stockpile resources now, you have no motivation to do quests, or everything you gain get burned.All my DLC are next to useless now.All my premium ships are next to useless now.All my time spent on leveling progression ships is wasted now.This is official cheating from developers.Conclusion: Targem and Gaijin combined efforts have killed StarConflict. Not worthy of your time now, not recommended anymore. R.I.P.Yes this Review is copy paste one to one from  my friend and wingmate Devouder. And he beat with then the nail on thead.I loved the game, spend a lot of hours in there and now.. i see them fall.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Old review was outdated due to significant changes to the game. Many good, many bad. Pending finalization and personal experience with these changes, I will update my review then.Don't assume old reviews are still true. A lot has changed. Many of the old positives are gone, and in exchange not nearly enough of the negatives are addressed.This game had so much potential. Each of the hours I've played prior to the Destroyers release was fun in one way or another. But since then, disaster after disaster has come down the pipeline, and the devs don't seem to care. Any game that's like that, you should stay away from.Don't play it. It used to be incredible. But not anymore.If you're curious about how my opinion has changed over time, the best way would be a ratings scale with time:July 2014 (Started playing): 7/10August 2014 (1.0 Release) 8/10April 2015 (1.1.3, Dreadnoughts Release) 8.75/10May 2015 (1.1.4) 9.25/10September 2015 (1.2, Dogs of War, Ms Summer Quests) 8/10November 2015 (1.2.3, Sweeping changes to rank-based queues) 7/10December 2015 (1.3, Destroyers Release) 5.5/10March 2016 (1.3.4, T4 Destroyers) 4.5/10April 2016 (1.3.5, New "Ship-Specific-Parts" system) 4/10June 2016 (1.3.8, Currency counts increased again) 3/10MOST RECENT AS OF THIS REVIEW:October 2016 (1.3.12, T5 Destroyers, affirmations of all previous bad decisions) 2/10

												Nope -- just nope. Gainjin seems halfway decent in War Thunder, making the grind not so bad.  This game on the other hand is a damned grind-fest. We play games to wind down after work, they shoudln't feel like a second freakin' job. Also, dunno if the admins are from gaijin (I wonder) or from Star Gem, but they... are bad.  I felt like the several interactions between players and the company's lackeys was very unprofessional and felt like the admins were 12 year olds on a power trip. They're also extremely absusive towards players, and dish out lots of trash-talk but can't take a professional sounding rebuttal.  Kind amakes me sad because the engine behind the game is really good, and there is a lot of potential there for them to have an excellent game, easily outclassing many others in the genre.  But the company's incessant demand for pay2win and abusive admin/GMs ruin the game.
