number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13
												Star Conflict survives because it is one of the few games that does what it does.Pro's:Nice, quality graphics that are at the right level of detailLarge-scale, small-ship battles. If anoyne knows another game that does that (and isn't 10 years old with a dead playerbase), let me know.Interesting world with an evolving (if very hidden storyline).Relatively decent assymetric balance outside noted below.Con's:PAY TO WIN. This game is about as pay to win as you can get. TECHNICALLY you can get everything in the game with sufficient grind. But sufficient grind for the latest and greatest items is measured in months or even a year, by which time it's been nerfed, and the cycle has started again. And the latest items ARE the greatest. If you've got a gaming wallet with thousands (Not an exaggeration, by the way), then this game might be for you.Awful developers. Extremely sensitive to feedback, any post on the official forums that is slightly critical gets deleted rapidly by moderators. If you don't have a direct line (pay to feedback maybe?) to the developers, you aren't getting heard unless it's sunshine and roses.Awful server availability. This depends a little on where you are, but over half of the games will be played on Russian servers, and ping matters for true competitiveness. If you live in Europe then this isn't as much of a consideration.The community is about average for a free, competitive game, at least the English-speaking part is. No more toxic than most, but no less.Overall, there is plenty in the game to enjoy but it's spoilt by terrible balance towards extreme wallet warriors and devs that focus on short term cash decisions.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												Played only for a whileEnjoyed the undock option and going through portals and whatnot(was well done)PVE and Co-op was alright (in terms of gameplay and such)General gameplay pretty good, what kept me playing for a while.VERY optimized game, not balanced at all though. Would not recomend it since it's big P2W game. I used to play this when it first came out and it was a lot of fun and more balanced than I thought it would be. But coming back to this a couple of years later it feels redundant and unbalanced, where as before it feelt like my skill had an impact on how well I peformed it now feels how much I've payed dictates that. The fact that PVP always teams you up with people using destroyer class ships and can annihilate your ship with only one or two shots says something about PVP. Or the fact that people in co-op or PVE also kept doing the same thing. Don't get me wrong I played tons of the matchs and I always got first, second or third, except for PVP. They all had something in common though, the top players would had max synergizied ships and annihilated everything in a couple of hits. This was either due to them having BOUGHT things to further their powers or matchmaking simply being awful and having no other choice then team you up with vetereans. Either way Would not recomend this game. For this kind of game it feels like it should be possible for players to have somewhat of an effect even if they're free to play players based on their skill, manuevring and risk assesment. But it seems the devs takes the free to play idea in a ball and give the p2w bat to the buyers and lets them hit it out the arena in a homerun.

												Retried Playing, seems the devs first ask "can we make money on this update", if yes, push it out immediately, even if incomplete. then the second question is "how can we make this impossible for people who don't pay?" and balance accordingly to that.PvE: get past T3 ships and want to do PvE with your new T4 ships? Tough luck, you'll die in seconds no matter which ship it is. The Teirs for PvE are so wide they become impossible without a team that has the higher teir on the spectrum.PvP: Dead. Litterally go kill yourself before playing T3+ PvP. The matchmaking places the New T4 destroyers down into T3 PvP matches. They insta kill the T3 destroyers making them worthless. along with every other ship in T3 and T4. The game basically says "hey look at how these new destroyers totally ♥♥♥♥ you up! Even though they aren't in the same teir!" yeah, or I can say ♥♥♥♥ the matchmaking for PvP untill it's fixed.OpenSpace: now requires Higher Rank ships to access. Works Better now. HOWEVER. it's boring as ♥♥♥♥. there is almost nothing to do. you'll get killed by the Aliens easily no matter what rank ship you have (except destroyers OR running away with tacklers.) oh, and now there is an absurd resource grind in open space. the dailies make some things not so grindy. but materials like neodium, beryllium, or anything else that can't be obtained by salvaging modules can only be obtained out here... in incredibly small amounts IF you can even find a node that has them.Oh and be ready for the Synergy Grind.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Fun for a while, but like every freemium game, you get to a certain point of progression where it stops being fun and becomes a HUGE grindfest, requiring you to, you guessed it, give them money to advance at a decent rate.There are a number of balance issues in pvp, pve while fun gets repetitive and the free roaming feels very closed in and limited. There are some free roam NPCs in "high-sec" (for want of a better term, anyone that's played EVE Online knows what I mean) that annihilate rank 10 premium ships without a struggle, which further puts you off wanting to do any of the daily quests you get given.Graphically it's average, some aspects look really good but most of it is underwhelming. Aside from one patch that broke fps in the hangar for 2 days before they very quickly fixed it, it runs silky smooth. Any rig from the past 3-4 years should hit 60+fps easy.The one big problem I have with this game aside from the freemium aspect; the community. There are some very nice people that play it, but the majority just seem to be on a mission to do nothing but grief or troll 24/7, and a lot of people are just plain bad at the game. Most of these people are in clans. Any time I would play alone and do pve with randoms there would usually be one average-to-bad player and 2 clanners that don't communicate, resulting in almost certain failure.Play it with friends. If you can't convince friends to play with you, do your very best to remain patient and prepare yourself for inconsistent PvP match-making and rage-inducing PvE teammates.

content:
Posted: February 19
												The only reason I can't recommend this game is the Pay2Win setup. I played this game since beta, and I'm a returning player. It used to be really fun and anjoyable, and fairly balanced. But now, everything is nothing more than a microtransaction.Want to set a premade avatar? Real money. Want to build a ship? Grind forever or real money. Want to upgrade modules? Grind or real money. Want a ship that's on par with the P2W ships? Real money.Overall, the gameplay itself is excellent and the variety in ships is....average for the life of this game. Graphics are pretty good too. I like the pacing in the game when it comes to combat. Other games with a similar feel (Dreanought and Fractured Space) are too slow for my liking.The devs also are super restrictive with their forums. Need a guide? Don't bother. All the posts are a year or more old. All posts require dev approval. At the time of updating this review, I've waited almost 2 weeks for a forum post to be approved for a guide (probably why the forums are dead). Don't bother criticizing their devs on their forum though, those posts are immediately deleted from what I've been told.All-in-all, it's free. Give it a shot and see if you like it. I'm leaving my thumbs down because there are some serious progression/grind flaws, lack of dev transparency, and obvious P2W issues. But the gameplay itself is good once you spend weeks upgrading modules to be useful, lol

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I highly recommend this game. I like to play it daily, but never for more than an hour or two. Lets begin with the fact that it is free to play. In Star Conflict you pilot a space ship in approximately 10 minute matches. The matches include; Combat Recon: a deathmatch like game where two teams face off against each other and may respawn after death only as long as their captain is alive. Detonation: A capture the flag-like game where two team attempt to pick up a bomb and deliver it to enemy stations, winning when no enemy stations remain. Capture: Is a three point domination game where holding a base is worth points, so which ever team holds the most points over a duration will win. Domination: Is an elimination match, you when when you cap three enemy bases or you kill the enemy team. Hunt: Is a one moving point domination game where one of three points is active for 70 seconds during which the team who controls it earns points.Players advance through a ranking system by earning credits (money) and synergy (xp). Players quickly gain access to three different hull types; Interceptors: Small-sized, lightly armed and shielded, agile, fast ships. Fighters: Medium-sized, heavily armed and lightly shielded ships. Frigates: Large-sized, heavily armed and shielded, slow ships. For the three hulls there are three sub-classes for every hull type. For Interceptors there are Covert Ops, Recon, ECM, each specializing in defeating a particular type of ship or performing a particular task. For Fighters there are Gunship, Tackler, Command. For Frigates there are Guard, Engineer, Long Range.There are three factions, being a member of a particular faction will only determine who your opponents are. A player may purchase ships from any faction. Within each faction is a ship tree showing all the ships available and the path you must take to unlock them. Each faction will offer contracts that reward the player with special currencies that will allow for upgrades of specific weapons.The game play is highly addictive. The controls are simple and intuitive. The game is enjoyable at every tier. Game servers handle latency very well. You wont get killed by the really laggy guy you never saw or not be able to hit the guy who skips all around.For a free game that states it is a BETA, the devs keep you posted about updates and changes to the game and there are frequent updates.My only complaint is that the player base is low, so the match making system can take 5 minutes to put you into a match during off-peak playing hours. During peak hours its usually under 30 seconds. In addition, the low player base forces the match maker to create matches that are slightly imbalanced ie everyone on the other team is more skilled than everyone on yours etc.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												A lobby based space shooter.What's good.1) Great space fighter with much more customization options than the rivals, through diverse module slot distribution and multiple types of weapons with interesting mechanics.2) Almost perfect free to play model. The grind is not too much (though it's certainly there), and the ships you can buy with money are not strictly superior (though they are better in some ways, just like every ship has their own quirks).3) Very nice gradual learning, you start with very few options, slower ships, only one game mode, and you ramp up the number of modules and modes you can use gradually through the tiers.4) Developing competitive side. Observer system already in place, tournaments are held, teams are preparing well ahead.5) Multiple game modes with their own interesting mechanics and multiple maps, some very imaginative.What's bad1) Low population, and all that comes with this. Sometimes long Q times for some modes.2) No skill based matchmaking, so everyone is thrown into the game as equals (except squads who have to be matched by an enemy squad), which sometimes lead to very unbalanced matches.3) The game is not really dynamic compared to shooters like Freelancer or even Moon Breakers, if you fly anything other than an interceptor than you usually strafe behind cover more than you dogfight, which is fine for frigates but a bit weird for a fighter.4) Somewhat lacking balance, one shiptree (graph) (Jericho) is considered strictly inferior in most areas to the others. Hopefully will be patched, and anyone can play anything anyways, it's not restricted, players don't belong to a side.All in all, a very enjoyable space shooter, even if somewhat grindy, but if you enjoy your game, you won't notice it at all.Sincerely: [NASA]fasz

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												My last review on this game was too much one-sided. Star Conflict has its upsides, such as a a great player vs. A.I. combat system, but a defunct and thoroughly unbalanced PvP Simulated Combat type. Its Matchmaking is on vacation, its open world is unbalanced depending on where you go, or what ship type you use and by that extent, what weapons and equipment you bring with you. If you are into grinding endlessly to get new upgrades in a show of pace that would make Destiny seem like a second-rate Duck Hunt County-Fair Game, then this is for you. If you like Big open-world maps with O.P. A.I. running amuk, then this is also the game for you. Star Conflict is not a game for wimps or players who give into stress-pressure too easily, or who quit after only less than 5 hours of gameplay. You ahve been warned: THIS IS A LONG GAME. It's long and difficult to gain rank and/or experience, and even more difficult if you dont give-in and buy GC with actual $$ to spend on new fully-maxed ships and upgrades, but it is still fun to an extent. If you like fast combat, slow grind, but attentive combat, then I would highly recommend this game. If you are into fast combat and equally fast tier-based ranking, like in games along the lines of Battlefield, Eve, and BattleStar Galactica Online, This is not the game for you, please keep scrolling or you will be surely disappointed. This game is focused on a select crowd of space-based MMO gamers. If you're interests match what has been described, then by all means, play. If not, then as I have said before, you have been warned.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												updated again: since the alien ships have come in and the new weapons, the game is highly unbalanced. It appears that the only way to truly enjoy yourself on this game is to play pve and open space missions. PVP has been completely ruined with the new ships, and it seems like they are increasingly hard to get without paying real money for the packages. IMO only play this game if you want to roam around in space, and it really is no longer worth it during pvp. After all the hours I put into this game, I basically never play it anymore because of this.Updated Review:So this has been my favorite game on Steam for a long time, and I have the hours to show for it. I like the  great graphics, multiple styles of space combat, and interesting missions. The types of ships always provide a new challenge, and they are generally fun to play.  You can go into open space, and fly around doing missions, or compete in PVE or PVP missions.    There are tiny Interceptors, Giant Destroyers, massive Corp ships (you dont get to pilot),  and new alien ships.  The game is constantly updated, and gets plenty of money so it is likely to stay for a while.  I would recommend this game for many reasons, most importantly because it is fun to play.  So that's the good part, and why I still say it's worth playing. My biggest issue with the game is that when a new piece of content is released, they encourage paying for the parts instead of building it the slow way. They make it really hard  to earn the parts for new ships. I personally invested so many hours into this game because I enjoyed making the secret project ships, (a top tier ship you can craft with parts you collect through gameplay).  The new alien ships, and even destroyers were easy to craft immediately if you spent the money. I find this both frustrating, and pointless. The premium ships and licenses are already available to reward game donors (of which I am one).   The new ships should require effort and playing hours to unlock, instead of repeatedly making plays for quick money.  I love this game, and will keep playing, but I refuse to pay to fast track any ships.  For those who read this review, I would say it can be a lot of fun to play this game, but don't bother paying real money to build your stuff. Just do it the slow way, and i fyou want to spend money, buy the DLC packages, and wait until a 50%  sale before purchasing.  You get GS, licenses, premium ships, and permantent bonuses. It's really the only value you get by paying into the game, besides supporting a game you play.

content:

												STAR CONFLICT EVOLUTION Complet Review!After a long wait it's finaly here! i'll try to make it clear and simple for everyone (dev and player)1--> GameplayIt's a arcade fighting game based, witch mean fast and intutive controles and where skill is about everything.Each ships in the game are different and make you enjoy a different gameplay every time you get access to a new one! ever players in the game have it's own build witch mean you'll never face the same thing over again.You also have plenty of game mode:PVPPVELeagueTournamentOpen SpaceSector Conquest (for Corporation only)In Star Conflict you are able to creat or be part of a team(or corporation) like any other multiplayer game. Once part of it, you can star Building a Dreadnought! (Yes a big freakin ship) that will allow you to take part in sector conquest, a game mod that alow you to take controle of a sector of the game and get you access to some pretty nice reward.2-->Graphic and VisualStar Conflict is a beautiful looking game, effect, background, ships visual, maps, everything make you enjoy flying around.In this game you are able to customize any of you ships! (exepte some few premium ships)from the paint to sticker, you can make your ship looking mean or just having a yolo paint (pink all the way!! :D) 3-->Storythere is no story mod but there is some kind of story in the background, and new content are delivered after each major update:-messages-crypted messages4-->MM and BalanceAaaah the famous MM! in most of multiplayer game this thing is annoying ^^! well Star Conflict is sadly in the same trouble! mostly noticed in tournament you'll fall againist way more stronger player witch will leave you unable to do anything to counter them, they are faster, stronger and know everything about the everyship in the game so you wont be able to take them out alone and that why team play is REALY important in SC! But now here come another probleme with the Update 1.4.0 Evolution, the first alien based ship, the worst nightmare of every player (even veteran) THE Thar'ga.This ship introduce a whole new systeme in term of upgrade gameplay and of couse power.The ship himself(without he's weapon) is pretty nice, fun to use, not unkillable everything is nice here. But there come he's modules and weapon.Thar' kth: can 1 shoot and interceptor.Alien intuition:65% more dmg once activatedCombat Reconstructor(special module):absorb 75% of all incomming dmg and regenrate your hull+ deal dmg to ship in a 500m radiusEnergy Converter: redirect all inncoming dmg into a beam dealing dmg proportional to all incoming dmg.teleportation sphere: can warp you in any direction on 2000mYes you get it. combine all of those you are -invicible-1 Shoot everything-get away in any situationAnd now imagine this ship used by 8 veterans players at the same time in the same team.haha fun right ? yes you can leave the match, but wont be able to use the ship you where using until the battle did not ended!so yea pvp in star conflict is now a real nightmare you can't do anything.5--> Ship SelectionStar Conflict have a realy nice list of ship and lot of different ship class and type:Interceptor--> 3 class: ECM(stunter) RECON(scout) and Cover OPS(Hit and Run)Fighter--> 3class: Tackler(skeaky killer)Command(Support) and Gunship(Firepower)Frigate--> 3class: Guard(tank) Engineeer(Healer) and Long range frigate or lrf to make it short(sniper)and Destroyer--> 1 classe: suppresor. made for those who like big ships ^^! all of these leave you with more than 200 ships! :D6-->Progression Progression is pretty smooth, due to a lot of game mod you are free to choose the best way for you to get better ships and equipements-->pve: if you want money and lvl up your ship in the calm -->pvp: if you are a competitive type player, have good reflex and like to learn the hard way this is the best mod to lvl up any of your ship fast-->spec ops: best way to get blueprint for better weapon or exclusive one-->open space: This is spaaaace! best place to get ressources, master your ship, test new build...7-->Q&AYou can of course make all of this faster with a premium license:50% more money 50% more synergi(XP) 2more loot spot 50% more voucher(used to lvl up you weapon)does premium worth it ?i'll say yes for a new player it realy help and make you save time, same as for premium ships.I saw there is some dlc for the game does they worth it ?Some of them give some realy nice bonus and ships, but you have to keep in mind that those are absolutly not nessary, you can make your way to the top without getting them, buying them is more like giving lovely support to the dev's team witch i realy like cause you speak with them anytime :) --> forum: https://forum.star-conflict.com/Is this game pay2win ?NO it's not! ^^ it's all about how you are playing! there is ofc a lot of stuff you can buy but it only make thing faster! it will never make you a more powerful player!after few hours of playing i notice some bug how do it tell dev's about it ?There is a bug report section on the forum is case it happen -->:https://forum.star-conflict.com/index.php?/forum/213-bug-report-section/this game is realy nice but i think it will be even cooler if dev's implement new stuff! how can i offer new idea ?Same as hearlier there is a forum section for it ! -->https://forum.star-conflict.com/index.php?/forum/230-suggestions/8-->Game evaluation After spending hours and hours on SC i've seem a lot of new stuff getting include and getting reworked the game always evolve and that a great thing! that allow player to get a new experience often and not get bored quickly.But since the Thar'ga come out it ruined the game, at least the pvp and every pvp mode like tournament (the worst) league (you can still win by rushing becon)I used to be a pvp player and i can't enjoy playing pvp as i do before. It become frustating and make often make me quit before the end of a simgle team battle ( the whole team getting spawn camp in a space game i mean cmon...)More update are in coming (like trading, more ship and with a Open Space rework)but if the game stay that way i'm affraid not a lot of new player will stay.I STILL HAVE HOPE!Season 2 Dreadnought update:8.5/10Dog of war update:9/10 Invasion update9/10Age of Destroyer update10/10Evolution Update6/10Endeav, Vice president of Stellar Marines.disclaimer* my current note migh change depending of how the game goes in the future, i can't recomand it for new players but at the same time i do, you can still give it a try!

content:
Posted: March 12
												Games okay till your ships reach rank 10 than that's when the grinding becomes heavy to get anywhere. It's a grinding game of coarse or you can pay for perks of different sorts but it's not cheap and the items are random in most purchase bundles. There is a high chance you will not get what you need in a purchased bundle sooooo they hope you buy another bundle"s" (get the idea? PAY). I find most bundles not worth buying for what they ask and ONLY make purchases when on sale if you GOTTA have it.This is a PVE and PVP game but unfortunately as of now if you hate PVP like I do your out of luck. The developers decided to put important items to advance in this game as rewards for completing PVP missions. To some people thats like making the lambs go beat up the lions. I wish they would have given an option on how to complete missions for rewards (PVP or PVE) instead of "forcing" a player into PVP missions. Let the PVP players feed on themselves ( I'm sure it won't be as fun or easy)Weapon critical damage is questionable. A weapon that does 2200pts normal damage can crit you at 30000pts damage (give or take, I've seen higher depending on weapon). This can successfully one shot you at full health and so playability withers away. Personally I can't believe how high crit damage has been allowed to go, it's not a fight anymore.From experience by playing these types of games I would say this game is at its middle of life expectancy and on it's way down. Being that items will always be added to this game to please the hard core players (and make money), things will eventually become overwelming and balancing issues will become more and more difficult (it's not good already). The game forum will eventually drive the developers nuts from the cries of players telling them to do this and to do that. I have seen forums shut down because developers dug a hole to deep to get out of and the game was switched into basic mode, done and over with, c ya later.Final comment: I do like how the developers do try and let the average player obtain hard to get items like the "destroyer" after its been out for a while and the hard core players have already got one or two. It has made a few dedicated players mad who really worked or payed hard to get the materials to build a destroyer but this helps keep balance in the game so there is less have and have nots and keeps the player pool going instead of people giving up. Free to try so try it out but don't start spending your money on this game till you know where it would help the most because there is a lot of things you can get that's just a waste. I recommended this game but I'm really sitting on the fence in the middle, be careful progress can be very slow and demanding at higher lvls and I myself have been playing other games because this and the fact I hate PVP.Updated: Don't bother with this game, the developers are really screwing things up for the sake of  money. Seeing player pool slowly going down because of this. So friggen time consuming and costly to get anywhere in this game that when you think your finally getting something done (illusion), the developers do another patch to suit their wallet instead of making sure they keep a player base going. The game seems to be taking avantage of players who invested so much money that it would kill them to leave so they keep paying in desperate hope of change. SAD01

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Edited: 4-12-17I have been a part of the Star Conflict world for years now. I've seen it through the ups and downs etc. But now everything has changed. It has changed from a fun, interesting game about cool theatrical arcade space dogfights to a slow, repeditive, and non-rewarding daily grind. It looks amazing, but unless you throw 500$ or 25 hours per day, every day at it, you will achieve nothing. Almost everything that used to be fun about this game is gone and replaced with more and more inhibitions and limitations. I truly wish that I could still give this game a positive review, but if I did, I would be lying. To myself and to everyone else. I did love this game so much, but It has turned in to hell on wheels. It is no longer going down-hill, but has crashed and burned at the bottom of it. Fox out.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												I'll start by saying I love this game. I set it aside from time to time but always end up coming back. The graphics engine is beautiful, if you like sci fi ships this game has them in droves. A vast array of technological marvels to fly around and blow stuff up with.  The flight and shooting mechanics I find to be very tight and responsive. Sound effects are spot on, very satisfying and visceral.The downside is the progression system is extremely grindy if you don't spend real money. Its not so bad if you are enjoying the gameplay, but sadly despite having several pvp and even pve modes, one can get burnt out because the gameplay itself doesn't vary much. Aim your reticle at enemies, fire until they explode, rinse and repeat. There are plenty of modules to give different abilities to your ship, hull and shield repairs, additional weapons or drones, disables, and while they do add variety I find myself wishing for a broader spectrum of tools to use to liven up the gameplay after a while.I do still greatly enjoy it. Nothing around that I'm aware of that scratches the same spacey dogfighting itch while also being accessible, populated, and beautiful. But do be aware that while the game does not have a hard pay wall, it does make progress difficult past tier 2 without at least a small investment. I've spent money on this game, more than I'd like to admit. But I do it because the core game is fantastic, space battle goodness that deserves to be paid for.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												I used to really, really love this game. It was practically the definition of a good space-dogfighting game, blending the simple fun of an arcade title with the variety of a futuristic space-combat "simulator" in a way that captured the best elements of both. Unfortunately, development has taken a turn for the worse and I've recently joined the roughly 40% of the registered playerbase that's quit within the past year.This game has become a classic example of a great idea with a poor execution. Players new to this title can expect some fun gameplay at first, marred by some big problems. More time is spent queueing for matches than actually in them. It takes forever to unlock new levels and upgrades. The game is almost entirely server-side and Russian-based, so EU and US players can expect input lag. The monetization scheme is overpriced and somewhat pay-to-win. The developers will try to deny or cover up the existence of bugs rather than fix them. There is no actual anti-cheat software of any sort (although admittedly the game's server-side nature somewhat limits cheating). The developers have a very limited and somewhat antagonistic relationship with the community. The game's glaring problems are common, known to the playerbase, and rarely fixed.A year ago I still recommended this game, but now this free title isn't even worth the download time. Check out the variety of other space-combat games Steam has to offer; give this one a pass.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												Only recommend because I feel bad about not recommending a game that a lot of people enjoy. Not for me. I dont feel developers should be allowed to accept money for in-game items that are subject to change at any point because the game is still technically in BETA. Figure out what you want to do then start charging. The game feels like its always wanting real money for something. Ammo, paint jobs, rolling on good items (with a very low chance of aquisition), ships, pilot license that expires and has to be renewed (gives XP boost that is almost necessary for any casual gamer). The list goes on. No one wants to buy a Corvette on Monday just to walk out to a Pinto on Tuesday, because your dealership is in BETA. This is a horrible way to run a game. PROS: Fast and smooth gameplay. Really is a good engine in my opinion. You dont HAVE to pay anything. CONS: Money Pit - Forever in BETA - P2W (Worst parts of F2P - You FEEL like you need to pay to compete)

The only downside to this game that I have found so far is the long wait times for finding a game. content:
Posted: November 17, 2013
												Star Conflict is a 3D PvP arcade space shooter made by Russian devs, with plenty of progression to go through, and a typically smooth difiiculty curve. It's been an excellent time sink for me, with a great concept with wonderful graphics (that still runs pretty nicely - with the exception of one map - on integrated graphics if turned down a tad) and a neat community that has its own quirks. As it's free, if anyone asked me whether or not to give it a go, I'd say absolutely. That's not that it doesn't have its problems, though.Perhaps the worst of these is the blatant monetization. It was less apparent when I started, probably a combination both of more monetization as you progress and more monetization as time went on, but at this point, it's practically screaming for money. There's myriad kinds of in game currency, eight of which are free, and one of which is premium. The primary currency, credits, is earned by simply playing - neat enough. But six of the remaining require you to do certain tasks while playing, many of which are extremely difficult. Even if you do complete some, these tasks are then put on cooldown for some value of time between nothing - for the lowest paying ones - or 17 hours - for the highest. Complicating matters further, one can only earn two of these six at a time, and must pay roughly 20 minutes worth of credits to change which two - or skimp out and pay with premium. These six currencies are used to pay for certain equipment upgrades, which can also be skimped out on and paid with premium. The other free currency not yet talked about is perhaps the only one in abundance that doesn't really encourage anyone to skip out and pay with premium for. The premium problem does go a bit further, yes, but not that much. There exist premium ships in the game, and while they typically have a slight advantage - easier progression, no upkeep fees, the tiniest of extra customization, get in the same queue as a slightly lower ranked free ship - they're not honestly that great. I've used one myself, and heard from several veteran players that they're not that much better, and in some cases, are even slightly worse than their free counterparts. Premium currency can be used for the things mentioned in the paragraph above, but those are mostly convenience fees, albeit "convenience" in the sense of "how it should have been done in the first place because the system is a tad bit too grindy for most people". But perhaps the biggest travesty is that customization of ships - and I'm not talking about buying passive modules and such - is so ridiculous. To buy a colour, one must pay roughly a dollar's worth of real world money. Each ship has three colours, even, so to fully customize a ship, that's three dollars. Now, that might not sound ridiculous, but these colours do not transfer to any other ship, and if you wish to change the colour once and then back again, you'll have to pay to change it twice. Same deal for stickers. You can't simply "unlock" a colour or a sticker, neither for your fleet nor for you ship, but must instead buy them on a per-instance basis. Now, all that said, would I still recommend this game? Hell yes. Even if monetization is being pushed ridiculously hard, it's still a /good game/ at its core. There's no other game out there that makes use of the third dimension like this one. The mechanics are still wonderful as ever. My favourite part is that skill is valued over hardware, 90% of the time. There's both a casual base and a competitive base, so there's neither a push nor a restraint on getting better at the game. There's an official forum where the active community gets together and talks about the game, as well as whatever else. And asking for help gets you help, almost always. tl;dr : The game is great on graphics, sound, mechanics, community, and originality. It's got huge problems on the monetization front, as well as some others not mentioned in the review (lack of tutorials, bad playerbase/dev communication, lag, newbie hunters, and community drama), but it's still a great game.

Devs are shady, and the game has become unbalanced. Its definately pay to win now in the since of destroyers.Destroyers are a new ship class they added to the game that completely annihilates everything, They are very unbalanced in the since of their tanking and fire power and often; but not always the team with the most destoryers wins.  Its not impossible to get everything in the game legitly, Its just it takes so long its not worth it. I spent 355 hours grinding for my Destroyer in this game, where as if i spent 20 dollars give or take I could have shaved off 200 easy.  This game did not start out as a pay to win craper, It kind of just decayed over time. So my recommendation is Its worth playing for a bit, but not worth putting money into it. It still gives a unique experience that I think is worth exploring. Beyond that though don't waste your time!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												 Pros: 1. Visceral and intense space combat. 2. Graphics are stunning and don't cause too much strain on my system. 3. Large 15 ship Tri-Tier for each of the 3 factions available.Cons: 1. Not very easy to find out what each piece does. Nor a in-depth explanation in how to use the pieces.  2. Be advised that buying a Tier 6 ship with paid for in-game currency, while having lower Tier ships. Will result in you being placed into higher tier matches. So if you're looking for a challenge, where you are limited to high enough Tier ships, go for it. Otherwise, I would suggest waiting until you're a higher Tier. ( Tier 2 ships unavailable for use with a bought and paid for Tier 6 ship. ) Suggestion only: Instead of just having Holiday sales. Maybe add some Holiday type weather? Or Spacial anomalies?

Posted: March 13
												used to play this game for a long while, until I got bored of this game. The space combat is cool and all but building ships takes a long to do, unless you pay for the bundle packs in the game in which your chances of getting the item or rare part you trying to get will random and pay again and again... you can go mining in open space but that will take too long, sense it's random what you find from astroids and ships that got destroyed and drop random stuff too. Tho you can do matches with some random players in co-op modes, pvp, or special opperation, you get a high chance for rare Random loot pick ups just by clicking on what you clicked on you only get a few chances tho like 4 or 3 I think? Only at the end of the match win or lose I think? been too long since I played StarConflict. Good luck to anyone wanting to build a destroyer, good luck... That's one issue I have for building ships I wanted to build, takes a llllooooonnnnggggg time. Unless you pay for the bundles then you saved your time. And then the gameplay... The matches feel too much of the same to once you play them. Over and Over again. This game has the phone game app feeling in it, I mean jsu t play it for a good few hours and then you know that feelong too the maps get boring after a while. You play the same maps many times, Yeah I know the game random picks the maps for you so that you don't have to vote for which map you wanted to play. Makes it little better from the repeditive gameplay you'll experience in this game. You won't get easily killed as a level 1 in co-op, until like level 6 then yeah you'll get killed easily, If your not reckless. PvP is alright, you can go and test your skills that you learned from playing and go against other players that may have stronger weapons and a better ship then you. The controls aren't much of a problem its quite simple in my opinion don't know about you. Weapons can be upgraded on the ship you selected, and other upgrades can be put on the ship for better performance of that ship, The AI decent and they are easy, hard or annoying to kill in co-op, if your not reckless that is... yeah you might get ganged up by a huge group of them and die. But the AI is easy, hard or annoying to take on. If you want to play this game, play if you want to experience a repeditive gameplay. Nobody wants that type of game downloaded right? Last but not least, the Factions. You can choose one the 3 or 4..? factions you wanted to join in and work them. But honestly, there is little to no diffence to whatever side you. They alll feel the same to each other, except for the missions they give to do. So it doesn't matter what side you choose. there is nothing that special that you do in any of those factions you join. There is nothing else left for any of them.. I give this game a 5/10 just a straight up 5/10 from little fun to boring.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												Edit: I'm rewritting this review, since there has been some changes after I wrote the original one.I've been playing this game for more than one year and I think I can give you a balanced review. First of all: This game is not Star Citizen, or Eve Online or Elite Dangerous. It doesn't want to be either. This game is a lobby based, free to play fighting arena game, settled in space. You have several ships at your disposal, with different classes and a lot of modules and modifiers to customize their performance. Then you go into battle in teams against other people in several game modes like the usual team battle, king of the hill, capture points etc... So far really standard. We can say that it is very similar to Warthunder of World of tanks, but with spaceships regarding the pvp skirmish matches. Then you have also High end content for clans with rewards if you conquer some of the sectors, which is nice for hardcore players, since you can even win a few premium currency here and there.NEW!: High end content has been reworked and now you can battle other corporations with your own corporate dreadnought. The attacks and defences are all happening in the open world map, so it is all integrated in the same place, instead of random sectors as it was before. So far it looks nice and helps with immersion. Dread battles feel like a mashup of all modes, since you have beacons (dread tactical devices) bombs, and a lot of tactical choices. The battle feels gorgeous and I remember in the first 2 or 3 games I was just watching the new graphics instead of playing.The only problem so far is that most of the corporations just fight over the small sectors, and the tier 4 were contested in the first week and since they they haven't changed. I suppose with time more and more people will join the fray. But the tier 3 sectors are really, really contested.And finally, what makes this game very balanced is that you can also play missions or scenarios in a Co-op fashion with friends, or straight open world and do PvP (pilot killing) or PvE vs AI. The open world is not like Eve online, is more like a huge sandbox map, with some RPG like missions (go there, kill 4 wolfs, come back, go there, pick some asteroids and return) and people to interact with. But you have respawns and you don't lose your stuff if you are killed, so it is more arcadish.Good thing is that the open world comes with a simple manufacturing tab which allows you to manufacture special ammo, weapons and consumables with the resources collected in there, and also 3 top tier ships which can be configured as you want when you are building them. The business model is akin to said games (warthunder, world of tanks) so you have to play and unlock ships with experience, credits and several special currency to get better and better modules. Investing money in the game gives you economical advance, as it is usual in this games, but so far there is nothing you can get with gold that you can't get for free. You will just have it later. Concerning most of the complains about the pay to win in premium ships, premium ships are not better than standard ships. They have the same slots than their credit counterparts, and the bonus are different, but not better. Modules can be shared between ships so there is no difference either. The problem is that in the tech tree, the credit ships appear with their level 1 stats, and premiums always appear with full level, because they are sold that way. But after you level your credit ships you will see that the premium ships are not better. So my final verdict is still a 9, because the Dreadnoughts are still in developing (not tier 5 Dreads yet) but we are almost there. All other balance issues with the new consumables had been fixed, and currently only the Destructor weapon is a pain in high tier beacon games. But I hope they will fix it as well.PROS: - Good art and graphics. - Runs well in mid and low end computers. - Free to play, it won't hurt your wallet if you try it. - Fast paced action and a good number of game modes. - PvP, PvE, and a sandbox with both, all in the same game. - SPACE DUDE!! SPACE!!! CONS: - A good chunk of the population is russian, so expect longer than average waiting times out of russian or european prime time. - Servers are a bit unstable sometimes, but this is something I'm finding in almost any late game. - Population is not as high as in mainstream games like world of tanks or warthunder. You won't notice it in low - mid tiers, but top end content lacks a bit of players.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												It's a nice game overall. Perhaps the best space fight simulation game I've ever seen. I especially like the combination of sandbox flavor and "WoT" flavor: You can immediately jump into a PVP or PVE fight from the hanger, and you could also choose to loot resources by traveling through systems. Good news: your ship won't be lost if destroyed during a loot. Unlike EVE. That's good to know.   As most people have pointed out, like World of Tanks, this is a "pay to advance" game instead of a "pay to win" game. What you can really do is use dollars to: 1. buy premium ships and jump directly to the corresponding tier; 2. buy premium license to accelerate synapse and credit gain. Neither will help you win in the game. It might actually hinder winning, since jumping to high tiers means you lack the experience to fight those veterans.  Honestly, I might be one of the "wallet warriors" some people refer to. I'm willing to spend a considerable amount of dollars into a game that I really like. And Star Conflict is one of them.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												This game deserves more attention than it has gotten. The flight system is a modified version of the one used in Warthunder and expirienced players will have no trouble. It can take a few minutes to get used to flying with no down or up (because in space down is where ever the floor is and up is where ever your head is pointing, not because this is one of those crappy 2d space games), but it can by fun to disorient players by coming at them along an odd attack angle. The game forces players to think in 3d, going under and over to flank instead of around, because there is no down in space. The crafting system works well and forces you to carefuly consider your play style. Best of all the dreaded "Pay to Win" system is mor limited than most. Synergy (exp) transpher, DLC, and Premium ships are the only noticable advantages. Premium ships are usually much weaker than their Synergy required counterparts and are so over priced only the desprat and the rich bother to get them outside of a very generous sale every year or so. Over all the game is well ballanced (except for the occasional max level russian), and easy to play. There is controler support and Occulus use is avalable. The graphics are exelent if you can run at max level, and are better than many paid games.The only real drawbacks are the dwindling player base because the developers put all of the advertising budget into their flagship game Warthunder and allowd Star Conflict to fade into relative obscurity. It has a server infrastructure to match and it is not uncommon for the NA players to end up in Russian, Europian, and even South Asian servers with clear favoratim for Russian players as they are the majority of the population. However this advantage is waining as more and more internet lines are replaced with fiber optic cables.If youre a fan of arcade space flight and combat sims, this game is for you.

												This game used to be absolutely stellar and what I'd have considered to be one of the best F2P games on the market, as it was extremely fun and avoided the typical pay to win pitfalls.Recent updates however have taken much of what made it fun before (namely, ship flexibility) and restricted the living hell out of every ship type and role. number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I play the game for many years (3?). It's very nice and fun - until you get to rank 6. Then you either go farm open space or you may continue with arenas which turn into horrible pop-fest where you are the one being popped non-stop - and I'm talking about experience of above-average player. Still the game is free and initially it's fun so you should definitely try it.Pros:nicely designed arena instances (both art and tactical layout);good looking ships;different play style for different classes of ships;quick initial progression;nicely designed combat;interesting open space sectors / treasure hunt / crafting concept;game run well on old PCs;a lot of different weapon types;decent horizontal equipment progression;decent AI.Cons:"PvE" and "vs AI" modes are badly balanced after rank 6 - as rank 6 you'll face L9 NPCs with epic-grade equipment;as often happen in PvP arena games - pre-mades roflstomp casual players, you tend to lose matches much more often than win them;heavily P2W mid/end-game: most powerful ships (destroyers, crafted L15) must be purchased or require months of focused farm (for example after *2+ years* I'm not even close to get any of those - it will take at least +1 more year);mid/end-game progression is too slow unless you purchase premium status, combined with NPCs and premades killing you non-stop it feels like a visit to a dentist without painkillers;badly designed mid-end-game may turn your progression into vertical wall;open space / treasure hunt / crafting are underdeveloped and could take a lot of polish and improvements;scarce resources for equipment progression, no point to waste them until you get to rank 14-15 ships.Conclusion:game is very fun in the beginning, has awful mid/end-game and has very interesting (but underdeveloped) open space, treasure hunting and crafting concepts. Despite flawed end-game I like it more than all other spaceship MMO games as a casual player.

number of helpful: 18 of 35 people (51%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
AbstractI have been playing Star Conflict for so long...like, before Open Space was actually useful. I decided that it was probably time to finally write a review...especially since there is a bunch of reviews on here with people that are either grinding out hours on there to make a review look worthy, or have literally played the game for so long and then write a crap review about it. Star Conflict I would have to say is mixed up hard. In my honest opinion on the game, it has ups and downs. Some of the reviews are legit on here, others make no sense to me. Lets see what makes up the integrity of Star Conflict and then rate it.GameplayStar Conflict in a nutshell is a pew-pew-pew competitive space shooter with both massively multiplayer elements that rush stuff and a slower more singleplayer side. I remember a time when the game was in it's early stages and the dreadnaughts had no even come out. I can't tell if the game has gotten better or worse since then. There are multiple modes in Star Conflict; PvP, PvE, Co-op v AI, and Open Space; on the higher tiers you have Tournament level stuff where high level players can team up against each other or against a huge enemy. PvP is what you expect, You vs. the other team. In PvP, there can be different objectives, my favorite personally being Combat Recon; one ship on each team is randomly chosen to be the commander for their respective teams. Your goal is to destroy the enemy commander and wipe out the rest of the team. After the commander is destroyed, no more respawns are allowed for that team. This diversity in gameplay allows for a lot of different playstyles, which brings me to my next topic.The vessels and factions in Star Conflict are incredible. From what I've gathered, Empire ships are high fire rate, (relatively) low damage and fast. However, they also have really powerful and really slow sniper ships equipped with a thermal cannon weapon known as a "Disentigrator". Federation ships are basically support type ships that use drones and stuff. Their fighters tend to be really good with escaping enemy grasps and showing up from behind and taking out enemies. Jericho ships are basically go big or go home. Shield tanky vessels that are slow and deliver a punch of built correctly. Their fighters love to just tank damage. Each faction has their own ships and each ship can be of a different class and type. This variety just lets the player play like they want to. I like the giant tanky sniper/full frontal force vessels of Jericho origin (more on that later).The only problem I have with SC in the gameplay category is how certain things are done. You can manufacture ships (more on that in a moment), but the resources required for some vessels can take months to collect if done correctly and without buy stuff. I will say that SC is really good about not pushing pay-to-play stuff in your face, there is a screen that pops up about it when you launch the game, and if you close it, bam that's all you see. Open space was also a joke until Dreadnaughts came along that required Iridium to manufacture. There was no point to OS until then. Gaijin has gotten really good about it now and added a lot of features.Also since it's a match based (apart from Open Space) you have to enter a queue (like in war thunder) to get into a match, occasionally, it can be really bad, but on average it's fine and easily overlooked timewise.Downfalls and DestroyersMatchmaking can be a jerk sometimes. I'm a rank 9 or 10 (kind of in the middle) mercenary, and I'm continuously paried with rank 15 players if I throw my rank 10 ship into my ship pool. I hate the way that's done but anywhere before rank 10, matchmaking is fine. That's the biggest downfall I think.Another would be the resourcing you do to manufacture ships. I didn't make this pain in the neck process number one, because it's totally optional. :)Luckily, the best loot used for ships like Destroyers and Dreadnaughts are obtained through the loot drops at the end of battles. Like I said earlier, resourcing and matchmaking can be bad, but since they finally made OS useful with Destroyers and Dreadnaughts, it's not so bad. The turn out on this one however is that most people don't like the new Destroyers update. I don't know why, I think it's becuase they think it's unbalanced; but here's the thing. if you start out as a new player or stopped playing for a while, all the rank ups you get in a faction literally just hand you the components needed for the destroyer. BOOM. Easy as pie. And all the while you're accrewing the materials, you are earning money, making up for the 3 million credits you need to manufacture one. Dreadnaughts on the other hand require some more explanation.Dreadnaughts are about 10 fold or more, powerful than a destroyer. These massive battlecruisers are constructed by corporations (mainly corporations that house a group of 10 players, rank 10 or more). Corporations are like factions in the game. These dreadnaughts however take a lot of time to make, but once you do, your corporation can engage in sector combat...another gameplay mode. You can take control of sectors in open space. I think that's insanely cool, but thats just me.RatingsGraphics: 8/10 (Really nice, some textures can be made better, but the attention to detail on the guns (how they move with the cursor and whatnot, is really well done)Gameplay and mechanics:  6/10 (Can be improved apon still. Grinding out resources isn't my favorite thing to do, but the payout is about 80% worth it after you rank the ship up some.)Lore/History: 9/10 (Well done, each faction has leaders and each leader has their own biography. The stations themselves have lore and pretty much every sector has lore behind it as well. Very well done.)Downfalls/Repetitiveness: 5/10 (Very grindy, leveling up can be a pain in the neck after like rank 4 or 5, fixed by maxing out the synergy on your owned ships to increasy your fleet strength synergy gain percentage)Overall Rating: 7.5/10 (Best competivive F2P game I've ever played)

First Impression verdict.If you own an Oculus Rift then yeah you should definatly check it out but if you own ELITE DANGEROUS then there is no real reason to stay too long. I would love to see the game grow and be able to compete with its WW2 counterpart

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I downloaded this game a few weeks ago, and finally got around to playing it a couple of days ago. I've only spent a few hours on it so far, but from what I can see it's based quite heavily on in-game purchases and DLC... I'm anything but good at these sort of games however, and I very much doubt that I'll be able to progress to a point where moving forwards is only possible through buying licenses and currency.In the early stages of the game- it's fun and enjoyable. I haven't gotten into it seriously at all, but it's still good for just messing about and having battles. If you're interested in the space battle genre but aren't planning to make this game a lifestyle, I strongly recommend it solely for the fact that it's free, and the early levels don't require any additional purchases. I'm not planning to dedicate myself to this game fully, and as a result I can enjoy fighting in a few battles in the evenings and exploring. If you're hoping to become more absorbed into Star Conflict and dedicate more time to it- then I do warn you that you will need to be willing to spend a fair bit of money to progress.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												To quicky describe this game, I use, "It's like World of Tanks, but with starfighters instead of tanks." Now, for a longer description, this game is actually pretty damn good. It's got solid gameplay, nice visuals, and I really like it. There are three classes of ships, and three sub classes for each. The three classes are 1: interceptors, which are fast moving lightly armored ships, 2: fighters, which are medium armed and armored and overall versatile ships, and 3: frigates, which are big, heavy, and slow moving ships. I won't go in depth with the sub classes, but for interceptor they are recon, covert ops, and ECM; fighters get gunship, command, and tackler; and frigates get long range, engineering, and guard. Each sub class has there own special main ability, or 'module' and a selection of other modules which are unique to that sub class, and there is also a selection of other multi-purpose modules that are avialible to all ships, no matter the class or sub class. Now, I think I've gone on ranting enough for this game, and if you've read this far, you've probably got the general idea of the game. I hope to see you up in the battle feild!

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												I strongly recommend this game. While it is indeed, as they say, *grindy*, it is very fun to play.My hope is that they will decrease the grind later on overall, but if you focus on maxing outthe synergy of T1/2 you'll have a faster time synergizing the ship types you like to use in T3+. I suggest finding a good class after you finish T2, and grind it straight to T5. You'll be able to get the ships you want faster by using this method. Once in T5, you can even gain huge amounts of extra synergy.Of course, currently, if you want to transfer extra synergy to other ships that you just don't want to grind, you can simply pay a small fee to transfer the synergy from your T5 ship to your T3+ ships when you wish to skip a few ships to the one you like.Again, I really enjoy this game and will start playing it again as soon as I gain a computer that won't fry on me like the last one. :D                                 That is all                                                                           - WolfKhan

												This game is like World of tanks just in space, you have to grind spaces ships to get higher ranks while upgradeing your weapons and other cool gizmos. It has good graphics, the controls are abit confusing at first but you get used to them; their are loads of differnt types of space ships from Command ships to recon to guards all have differnt tactics of use. The grinds can be quite long but worth it.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												For starters this game is still in its beta stage (I believe) however they are making great improvements every month. The combat is extremely well thought out and functions just right for a game that's all about avoiding aponents and shoting them down wile keeping yourself alive. On high end PC's this game preforms flawlessly, but on lower end PC's you may get a lot of lag or very low res textures, but the game should still be playable.Soon enough open world exploarion wil be released out of its closed beta stage, and I believe that is when this game will really take off.Should you be considering this game, you should know that the leveling and equipment selections are somewhat ok. Those who pay will have a clear advantage over those who don't, but its not as though its impossible to do well without paying, it just requires a heaping load more of skill to succeed.I would seggest getting your friends involved too and communicating thourgh voice chat through steam. Being able to verbally communicate like you're the cast of some star fighting movie-spaceship-enterprise makes the combat and strategy tactics much better.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												1.250 hours on the clock. What more is to say?++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Update on April 2nd; 2015:Maybe it is time to add something in response to some other so called reviews around here:There seem to be some players, who are talking about abusive admins etc. Since more than 1250 hours active game time I have seen not a single use of admin powers in terms of banning, let alone abuse.If you carefully read through those comments, they later all have to admit, that they were swearing, talking about drugs, using political names etc. For that, they got warnings and chat-mutes of a few hours.And now, we have some bad mooded kiddies who seek their revenge in negative comments.I suggest: if you ARE interested in this kind of game, try it for free. If you later decide to spend money on a DLC or Premium, you can do so by a personal opinion. Until then, you can enjoy the game for free.++++++++++++++++++++++++++Well, apperantly a lot. First - like a lot of those games (War Thunder etc.) you need to invest some hours to learn the game mechanics and what ship is doing what. Second, you need some patience, as this game is more or less in constant development. Sometimes they make it better, sometimes they make it worse. But, after all, it is free, and it generates a lot of fun. Especially, if you do it with a buddy or join one of the (better) corps (like clans) to play this together. There is PvP, PvE and an Open World Mode called Invasion (involves some Aliens).There are Premium ships, but they have not more killing potential than other, normal ships - they just don't need repairs and generates some % more free synergy (to level your other ships).Hint: don't spend your real money for transferring this synergy, but if you want, invest it in a licence to get more loot. If you have any questions, feel free to ask or go to the official forum pages @ forum.star-conflict.com

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												I'll Admit not the Best Flight Sim in the world but it definitely fills the gap between great games like TIE Fighter and Star Citizen (assuming it turns out to be what the hype says it will be). Anyway there are many differen Ships, modules and  play styles that keep the game interesting. The devs are always adding new things and are expanding the game at a nice pace. The new open World mode seems interesting but I will hold judgement on that for now it's still new and there are things to e worked out on it. BTW - for New Players here is a Pro-Tip there is a steep learning curve when you first start out. Prepare to die alot and not get many kills, but if you stick with it things will get a lot eaisy and you will have more fun in the game.Good Luck and BTW the Emperor's Hammer is always recuriting new Pilots... http://tc.emperorshammer.org/index.php

												8.5/10People complain about the p2w things in game but really, the only thing I'm bothered is about how the first frigate long range missile can only be gotten by grinding quite a while.The reason why this game isn't p2w is because differences between ships are minimal. Sure, the next ship always costs a ton of money, devs really want you to buy it, but the next ship has like 500 more hull & 1000 more shield and like 30 more energy, which is pretty minimal in terms of difference. The game is actually quite fun. Just try it, it won't hurt.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												A simple review:  For a more oldschool gamer such as myself, Star Conflict brings to mind such classic space sims as X-wing series, Starlancer, and Freelancer - games I still enjoy to this day.  The atmosphere is impressive, both on the scale of the playing areas, and the soundtrack.  however, some of the sound effects have more business being in games that invovle an actual atmostphere and not the vacuum of space. Even one of my projectile weapons (one designed to be something like a shotgun for starfighters) sounds like an old shotgun sound effect.Graphically speaking, the game is simply beautiful, although the scenery outside the actual playing fields don't change much - you only notice this when flying in the new open space "invasion" mode.  In the PvE and PvP modes, which are much more faster paced and hectic, it won't be an issue.  Game play is relatively balanced, and constantly being tweaked, controls are fine tuned and adjustable, and the game can be effectively played with keyboard and mouse, gamepad, or joystick.If your pace is more MMO style, you can explore the relatively vast reaches of invasion space - the open world portion of the game.  For me, a guy who's perfectly content to explore this space in search of loot and crafting material, it stops just a little short of being fullfilling.  The mining opportunities are small, and the risks far outweigh the rewards, though considering the company seems to be pushing for more players to join the Invasion part of the game, as well as the crafting set up, this may change in the future.For clans, or "corporations" there is the conflict area of the game, where you and your corp fight for territory between the three main factions.  Can't say I've played this one yet, because a certain rank of ship is required, which is a shame...because it's the part of the game I was most excited for.overall, the game is much more than satisfying and enjoyable, constantly evolving - for better or worse, with an active support team involved in the game community, can't ask for much more than that.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Game is grindy, but it has a great potential and awsome fights. Best I've seen. I'd describe it as Team-Fortress Classic in space.Starting out all you want to do is get in fights and get kills, but that proves to not be the point. When you join with some better players you see that the ship's role (much like in team fortress) plays a major part in what you shold be doing.Since the devs do look for money and use a pay-to-advance-faster system it is a bit frustrating to see people move forward if they pay money, but the game is free to play and with the price that it's worth (in my opinion in the few tens of dollars) you can advance to a top T1 **easily**. When you're a top T1 you can play T1 and no one has an advance over you other than implants.Open space is nice but you really need a corporation (clan) for that, as well as dreadnaughts. You can use scanners to mine resources and advance a lot faster than you would otherwise. The community discovery is BAD and this is what really kills the game since you don't get a feeling of multiplayer when playing (no chat, no one uses voice in-game, no forums...).All in all the game has great potential, very very fun and addictive, needs more players.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This game is a ton of fun. It may not be for everyone, but I like it.I will admit that this game is a bit tough to get through the bot filled tier 1 phase, and then the early under equipped phases when you finally make it to a new tier. However, with some planning on what to buy and when, this can be mitigated somewhat. I think it does a really good job of converting some of the familiar traditional flight combat sim mechanics into a more twitch based space theme. It forgoes a good bit of realism, but allows for more interesting matchmaking game modes, and an arcadey shooter feel.I definitely suggest checking it out, especially since it requires no real investment to get started and look around.

												Game is grindy, but it has a great potential and awsome fights. Best I've seen. I'd describe it as Team-Fortress Classic in space.Starting out all you want to do is get in fights and get kills, but that proves to not be the point. When you join with some better players you see that the ship's role (much like in team fortress) plays a major part in what you shold be doing.Since the devs do look for money and use a pay-to-advance-faster system it is a bit frustrating to see people move forward if they pay money, but the game is free to play and with the price that it's worth (in my opinion in the few tens of dollars) you can advance to a top T1 **easily**. When you're a top T1 you can play T1 and no one has an advance over you other than implants.Open space is nice but you really need a corporation (clan) for that, as well as dreadnaughts. You can use scanners to mine resources and advance a lot faster than you would otherwise. The community discovery is BAD and this is what really kills the game since you don't get a feeling of multiplayer when playing (no chat, no one uses voice in-game, no forums...).All in all the game has great potential, very very fun and addictive, needs more players.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Pros:+Great gameplay+Tons of ships to choose from+Customisable ships, allowing for different playstyles for each ship+Amazing graphics and level design+At Rank6, you get to explore open world maps+Later in the game, you can completely build ships with specs that fit your playstyleCons:-Pay 2 Win (but I guess that's what happens when you make a f2p game)-Confusing hub interface for new players-Controls take some getting used to-Requires plenty of strategy-You aren't exactly told that you can build ships or that an open world exists until you get that far in the game, so there's hardly any way for you to find it out.-Building ships takes a long time, and is confusing for newbiesThis game is everything you could want in a spaceship mmo. Short of building your own ship model or altering its shape, you have plenty of freedom and a large range of ships, weapons, and modules to edit your ships. You can leave your station and become a pvp bounty hunter if you so wish, or you can fight for the side of the humans and go to battle against aliens. It's all very expansive, but a lot of it you end up being blind to until you can get there. Trust me, the game's worth playing, and it's worth playing a lot.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												As everyone can see i have alot of hours on this game. I have also played since the open beta so i have a good idea of how the game has changed over 3 odd years its been out. Take into acount when reading ANY REVIEW on this game that it is FREE TO PLAY and nearly all content bar premium ships can be obtained without spending money.i personally enjoy this game and its great to play with friends. The random people you will play with sometimes dont understand there role or teamwork like in most games.Pros-Due to the current changes you can get previously paid for ships without paying real money-Nice controls that are very easy to understand-Varied ship roles and classes-New destroyers and secret project ships are highly customizable-Free roam is really fun especially in squads (is limited to zones though) Cons-premium money system (payed for with real money)-There is ships that you can only get with money -The grind at later levels can be rather long just to upgrade weapons or single modules-The time and resources it takes to make a destroyer can take a long time to gatherThe tutorials are not very good so i would recomend trying all the ships as most fly differently.All the people who say its pay to win do not realise that the premium ships are maxed out versions of non premium ships. Also there are no weapons that are premium only.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Apparently going through a bad periode for nowPlease read full review, I often vote "meh" or neutral, since it doesn't exist I vote either up or down but its quite meaninglessIl be be more specefic of the cons, because the downside is what matter the most after your interested in the game--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Returning player, used to play before in 2014-ish, returned due to destroyer update (as I liked frigate gameplay, sadly now impossible to play)Is the game still enjoyable ? YesAs enjoyable as before ? NoBasically this game is a arena based gamePVP sets you in a arena with different objectives ranging for plantings bombs to team death matchs and capture points, you get unlimited respawn but in recon where the designed commander has to be alive to allow respawnPVE sets you in a different arena, sometime with 3 different section (allowing you to respawn after each section) or a 1 block mission like fire support (no respawn), objectifs are usually destroy designed targets/capture points/kill bossOpen space is explained in the rest of the reviewPros-Looks good-Ship handling is decent-3 faction to choose from with the only big game changer being the Long Range Frigate (LRF) for the Empire and Jericho as the ship capability are quite the same otherise for the same ship classes-Open space mod (more like linked arena maps, because its litteraly the PVP maps with bots & loot linked via portals most of the time)-Ship design is very caracteristic of a faction-Can run on potato PC-The game lore evolves with updates (some old map station in open space are now turned into wreck field)-Other stuff I didn't mentioned because I'm too lazy to remember themCons-New tiering / unlock system (January 2016) : For War Thunder players, its the same here minus the BR thingFor non War Thunder players : you have 5 tiers, to go the next tier you need to unlock every ship of the previous tier, so if your like 1 gameplay style your forced to play all the other one too if you want to unlock the next ship of your favourite class^This is one of the things that legit scares me, that system can as well act a scarecrow for new players driving them away and some already playing with itLRF rant mode on-Remember what I said about the LRF?Forget Jericho for 90% of the timeReview of Jericho LRF-Fire a manually guided torpedo travelling at ~500m per sec-AOE effect-Possible to detonate it at any moment-Create a radiation cloud dealing medium amount of damage for 6 second-Don't require a direct line of sight-Reload every 15 sec-Easy to dodgeCountersGuardian frigtate : module destroying any type of guided missileFlares : all ships can carry it and it reload rather fast, disable torpedo steering controlsSmall ships : outrun your torpedo speedReview of Empire LRF-Enter a sniper mod when activated, fire a projectile travelling at ~3km per sec-Weapon can't be fired directly after activation-Reload in 2.5 sec-Has +2km more range than a Jericho torpedo-Afterburn damage dealing 25% of you shot damage 0.5 sec later-Require a direct line of sight-Deal more damage than a Jericho torpedo-Hard to dodgeCounters-Solid cover-Small ships : hard to aim-Engineer shield wall wich nearly no one ever useDue to the huge firerate / projectile speed and countermeasure gap, torpedoes falls flat into the utteraly useless sectionLRF rant mode off-With the destroyer update frigate gameplay pretty much died outGuardian basically play the same role as their name, they guard allies with powerfull defensives modules, and act as meat shield so they got one of the best HP & shield stats, its good defence is countered by bad offensive capacity (mind that a figher is outgunning you)Destroyers get 3x their HP & shields stats, they are more bullet spongy (is that even a word?) than the ship with this specefic role in mind with the icing on top being actually able to kick asses and move fasterThe only viable firgate are engineers because you will always need a healer and the Empire LRF because of reasons stated earlier-Open space is generic, nothing special happen, bots go in, fight each other, rince & repeat, no event ever happen (not even sure if the alien invasion event still occure since open space was launched)There is really no point playing this mod aside from destroyer part grinding (wich will take weeks to months at least or half the component) and some blueprint for some modules / guns--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Speaking of destroyers, after reading negatives reviews (yes I read the negative one before the positive ones)  Il give you a tipOnce you can make one (assuming you didn't died of old age grinding the parts for it), take a screenshot where it says you have the ressources to do so, because from what I read of some negative reviews is that the support might give the "no proof no refund" excuse, if your game crash / get logged off when building one and it waste your ressouces for nothing in return, you have a proof to back you up
