number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Yeah ok. So I only have about 13 hours in this game at the time of this review. Either way, its enough to give me a relitive idea about this game.Pros:+ Relitivly easy to pick up if you have played war thunder+ Map design is top notch+ Some maps contain easter eggs (A few maps have souyze capsules floating around. Also a possible reference to gailin being a russian company)+ Combat is nicely paced, with a ship type for everyone+ Each faction feels sort of unique, especially in terms of ship design+ No ship feels pointless (So far for me)+ PVE integration is rather impressive+ Feels fun when in a balanced match+ Huge amount of content means that gameplay itself is rarelly ever boringCons:- Gameplay is tedious at times- The grind at times can be painfull, especially the synergy grind- Some weapons feel a little bit unbalanced, namely coil mortars- PVE tends to suffer from a serious lack of corrdinated teams, in the one game type that demands corrdination.- Match search times tend to be very slow.- Small team sizes plus team balance based on ship tier means that PVP can end up being rather unbalancedSummary: The second you get into a balanced match in game, there is no other game I would rather play. There is no such thing as an average match. There are only painful matches, and awsome matches. Unfortunatly, the second you get into a badly balanced match, all the fun seams to leave this game. Although there is this problem, open space is always open and suprisingly fun. The real danger to this game is the boredom of looking for matches. Still, the cross game bonus features do make it worth trying out to at least get something out of this game.8/10 Overall

												If you like games about flying a spaceships - Fighters, Interceptors, Frigates... this is game for you.It's like World of Tanks in space with more classes and moddifications that can change a lot about your ship later on!It's not Pay to Win but some people might feel this way. The only thing you get for using real money is coloring, more synergy (exp) on stuff you upgraded/bought with real money (no super stat boost, just 3%more synergy for each upgrade with cash) also some boosters like bonus loot searching or more exp for all players in your team... premium ships too... (the only difference is that those have different slots for different modules than their normal conterparts)Did I mention that you get gold (irl money in game currency) for scoring steam achievements?

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												Fun space shooter game if you like a more arcade-ish experience.* It's not a space simulator akin to Elite: Dangerous.* It's not as big and complex as something like EVE.* It's more of a dog fighting game.Pros* Attractive.  Graphics are really nice, and it runs good on modest hardware.* Fun.  The game play is pretty fast paced and it can really be a hoot (most of the time).* Easy to play, difficult to master.  It's quick to get into a game and start playing.  There's a lot of depth in the ship bonuses and modules, so although it's simple to pick up and play, it would take quite some time, effort, and research to really raise the bar on your play through your ship configurations and item acquisitions.  This is a pro though, because skill and wisdom really does shine in this title.* Real time action.  A lot of MMO-type games use auto attack and auto-aiming abilities to overcome network delay (Star Trek Online, I'm looking at you), but this one requires you to actually be a good aim with a majority of the weapons -- they fire where you point, not what you are locked onto (missiles do auto target though). * High quality.  It doesn't feel cheap or play cheap.  The artwork and coding in this game is superior to many other F2P titles.  Though it's produced in Russia, which might be a warning flag to some, it's on par with AAA titles and is definitely legit.Cons* Lag.  I get a moderate amount of server lag in NA (rubber banding specifically; so packet loss and ping spikes).  I have insanely fast internet, and I ping major urban areas sub 30.  Granted it's very brief, but it happens fairly frequently.  Open space seems the worst for this.* Grindy.  Let me repeat.  GRINDY.  If you hate games that take a large investment of time, you probably won't care for trying to get to the higher tiers in this game; it grows exponentially harder than the lower tiers.  That said, there are often bonus weekends of +50% for everyone, and you can buy in-game subscriptions with GS (paid currency) that is strictly earned in game.  But it's not often nor easy (you gotta be an achievement hound and can really only swing the 3-day sub, so do it on the bonus weekends!).* Lower tiers need more content.  Literally, I played the same 3-4 maps for days until I ranked up to the next tier.  Bleh.  Why not scale all the maps and enemies to be based on team rank??  I couldn't do open space until rank 6 or so.  This could cause a new player to burn out very quickly.* Pay4Convenience, aka pay2getahead.  Let me be clear: it's not pay to win.  But since everything requires grinding (and quite a lot of it), you can bypass a majority of the grinding by simply opening the wallet.  The advantages of some of the paid ships are a little staggering in terms of the time it would take to do it in game, particularly for higher tier ships.  For low tier game play, it's really not bad at all.  That said, most things can be obtained in game if you are careful with currency and diligent in your efforts (read: not most people, since there's a lot of guesswork involved).  Some things are pay only (special ship skins, basically).* Item gap and/or Skill Curve.  Maybe it's people leveraging their paid currency and synergy bonuses, but the game seems to go from stupid easy to WTF hard.  By rank 3-4 you end up being one shotted by players in PvP and even a lot of ships in PvE.  So you'd do good to save up and focus on your modules and weapons, because the scaling is a little brutal when the training wheels come off.Overall, for the price (free!), it's good times.  It's worth an install and a try, you have nothing to lose afterall.  I would recommend this game for anyone who enjoys space and sci-fi shooter games.  It plays a bit like FPS games as well because of the twitch game play style, so it should appeal to people of other genres as well.It's just a solid, well polished, shooting game.  If that appeals to you in any fashion, definitely give it a try.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Don't let the trailer fool you about exploration, there's only instanced pve missions and arena pvp. From what other players told me there's no actual exploration of any kind, so I guess you can say it's a soft lie from the development team. To me, Star Conflict is more akin to a watered down version of X-Wing vs TIE fighter with nice graphics and MMO-style ship abilities. I spent my teenage years playing Space Combat & Exploration games like Freelancer and X3TC so I'd rather play an older, more proven space combat-sim over this particular piece. I have played a ton of war thunder and a little bit of star conflict in the past. This game was fun for a few hours but quickly got old as I began to see many parallels between both games. Many players on the NA servers complain about not getting a voiced opinion about ways to fix or make the game better to the development team and there is a constant stigma about Gaijin not caring about their community at all. Furthermore, the grind from ship to new ship or weapons is pretty condemning as far as time consumption goes, and I can't speak on gameplay balance. As far as being free-to-play games go the monetization is about average: Stuff is cheap enough that people feel constant pressure or incentive to buy, and pricy enough that Gaijin sees lucrative profit for even the smallest purchases.All in all I will say this though: If you're looking for a game to tide you over until a new space-sim/etc. comes out, star conflict might be an okay choice, but I don't recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game, because I love space games. And when I saw the control scheme, I really found myself wanting to love it even more, because I was a Freelancer junkie for a long time. But sadly, it's just a grind designed to wring money out of your pockets. There's a long grind between the part where you start playing, and the part where you get access to the interesting parts of the game. If you don't want to do a LOT of PvP, then just get out the wallet.Single player tasks become available fairly shortly, but it will be a long time before they don't just grind you up.The game often tells you it will take you a maximum of four minutes to get into a multiplayer game with an average of one minute, but that is a lot of nonsense. A small percentage of a time, you will be matched into a game immediately. Most of the time it will take well over a minute, and sometimes it will take six, eight, or even give up and go play something else minutes.

												Player beware.  This is an online PvP based game with some PvE.  As all online games you have to deal with the constant cowardly acts of exploiters and hackers, and as usual the delusional developer.   The PvE mission are good, but repetitive.  The open world PvE is lacking a way to progress to next ship, no constant way to get synergy to lvl.   If you have no honor and use exploits/hacks this is right up your alley.  If you like space combat in PvE settings and can stand repeating missions to level and some open world gathering of mats for crafting.  Keep in mind if you die you lose those mats in your really small cargo hold,  fyi the aliens that invade 2 shot you.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												This game has run in the background without me wanting it to, and I've somehow logged 50 hours.  The main content seems to be space shoot-em-up stuff, with lousy controls and ridiculously short effective ranges on the weapons.  Like -- putting  any range limit on weapons in a space game is already absurd, but the weapons I started with have way shorter ranges than you even see in other space games.  The only good thing about this game is that it reminds me of Freelancer, which is good because it helps me realize there are better things to do than play this game.But seriously, what was the game doing after I closed it, for 48 of those 50 hours?  Pointlessly using up my system resources keeping the game assets up in case I want to play again?  Recording and sending my passwords to hackers in some foreign country?  Nothing, because it's a dumb glitch?  I  can't tell.

Graphics are really nice, and it runs good on modest hardware.* Fun.  The game play is pretty fast paced and it can really be a hoot (most of the time).* Easy to play, difficult to master.  It's quick to get into a game and start playing.  There's a lot of depth in the ship bonuses and modules, so although it's simple to pick up and play, it would take quite some time, effort, and research to really raise the bar on your play through your ship configurations and item acquisitions.  This is a pro though, because skill and wisdom really does shine in this title.* Real time action.  A lot of MMO-type games use auto attack and auto-aiming abilities to overcome network delay (Star Trek Online, I'm looking at you), but this one requires you to actually be a good aim with a majority of the weapons -- they fire where you point, not what you are locked onto (missiles do auto target though). * High quality.  It doesn't feel cheap or play cheap.  The artwork and coding in this game is superior to many other F2P titles.  Though it's produced in Russia, which might be a warning flag to some, it's on par with AAA titles and is definitely legit.Cons* Lag.  I get a moderate amount of server lag in NA (rubber banding specifically; so packet loss and ping spikes).  I have insanely fast internet, and I ping major urban areas sub 30.  Granted it's very brief, but it happens fairly frequently.  Open space seems the worst for this.* Grindy.  Let me repeat.  GRINDY.  If you hate games that take a large investment of time, you probably won't care for trying to get to the higher tiers in this game; it grows exponentially harder than the lower tiers.  That said, there are often bonus weekends of +50% for everyone, and you can buy in-game subscriptions with GS (paid currency) that is strictly earned in game.  But it's not often nor easy (you gotta be an achievement hound and can really only swing the 3-day sub, so do it on the bonus weekends!).* Lower tiers need more content.  Literally, I played the same 3-4 maps for days until I ranked up to the next tier.  Bleh.  Why not scale all the maps and enemies to be based on team rank??  I couldn't do open space until rank 6 or so.  This could cause a new player to burn out very quickly.* Pay4Convenience, aka pay2getahead.  Let me be clear: it's not pay to win.  But since everything requires grinding (and quite a lot of it), you can bypass a majority of the grinding by simply opening the wallet.  The advantages of some of the paid ships are a little staggering in terms of the time it would take to do it in game, particularly for higher tier ships.  For low tier game play, it's really not bad at all.  That said, most things can be obtained in game if you are careful with currency and diligent in your efforts (read: not most people, since there's a lot of guesswork involved).  Some things are pay only (special ship skins, basically).* Item gap and/or Skill Curve.  Maybe it's people leveraging their paid currency and synergy bonuses, but the game seems to go from stupid easy to WTF hard.  By rank 3-4 you end up being one shotted by players in PvP and even a lot of ships in PvE.  So you'd do good to save up and focus on your modules and weapons, because the scaling is a little brutal when the training wheels come off.Overall, for the price (free!), it's good times.  It's worth an install and a try, you have nothing to lose afterall.  I would recommend this game for anyone who enjoys space and sci-fi shooter games.  It plays a bit like FPS games as well because of the twitch game play style, so it should appeal to people of other genres as well.It's just a solid, well polished, shooting game.  If that appeals to you in any fashion, definitely give it a try.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												An absolute must for Space Sim enthusiasts who also enjoys competitive multiplayer. The game isn't an MMO in the traditional sense but a matchmaking engine for up to 10 on 10 team based multiplayer action. There is also a PVE portion which is also multiplayer based. The game is gorgeous and has surprising deep gameplay as combat gets increasingly complex as you go up the ranks. The game is very well balanced with different ships providing different combat roles and nothing feels overpowered. Ship customization options are diverse and enjoyable. I've been playing for almost 100 hours and still find myself drawn to the awesome gameplay and graphics. An incredible value for the Free price tag. Just Wow!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Star conflict is a MMO, action and is also a free to play, which is always a good thing. The game is base in the near future, in which there are three factions; Empire, Federation and Jericho, which all have Interceptor, Fighter and Frigate classed ships.The game is fun, but for those seeking a realist space simulator, don't bother with this game. It isn't anything close to simulator. But for those looking for a game, which is fun and easy to play, then look no further.Since the game is Free to Play, it is to be expected that this game would have mini-transactions and DLC, which in this case, it does. The DLC ships and the in-game "licences" doesn't make much a difference, but I just helps you get more in-game-credits. Also, the Dev's inplemented a Achievement-ish bonuses which allow you to get the premium credits, but it is rare.In conclusion, I find this game highly enteraining and easy to play. Also, the game isn't strictly a "Pay-to-Win" which is always good, in which the game gives you, occasionally, premium credits. I would highly recommend the game to anyone looking for a simple, easy, fun and free game to waste your time in.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												first off i would like to point out that the game isnt MMO it is lobby based and the game was made by the same people who made War Thunder but dont give your hopes up. If you were expecting some MMO action you have to "earn" it through rank progression. once you reach rank 6 you unlock the tab "undock" wich allows you to roam freely into open space. i would deffinately recommend having equally strong firepower and a buff shield that way you can stand a chance against space pirates, cybers, and marauders. aliens on the other hand are going to overpower you big time.Now when i mentioned MMO it isnt entirely mmo. In my experience with open space i hardly came across other players. ive yet to join a corporation (clan) so i havnt quite got the feel of all the action yet.Now before you get to undock you have to progress through the different tiers of ships. you have Frigates, Interceptors, Tacklers, and commanders. some of those ships will share some abailities with each of them, but not all. when you first start off playing in tier 1 it will be relatively easy. once you reach the next tier things will toughen up a bit. modules, better upgrades, and buffs show up into play. alongside that not many main weapon choices are available until rank 3 or 4. making tier 2(+) allot harder until you make some fine adjusments to your starships. This can be a realy fun game or one of the worst games you ever played. just dont go in expecting much, dont pay for things given the fact that it is free to play, and have a good attitude overall. allot of things have changed since the launch of star conflict. im pretty darn proud to have this game in my library.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Considering the fact that this game is free, I am absolutey blown away by how amazing it is! It is very easy to customize controls, allows FULL controller support (so far I have been able to do 99.99% of things using an XB1 controller), as well as Oculus support and pretty smooth gameplay. Although initially learning about all the details (kinetic energy, synergy) was pretty confusing, it all starts to make sense after awhile. I still have quite a bit to learn in order to conquer the game. I play on an HP Beats Edition laptop, and I maintain usually 45 fps in game.One of the only cons I can think of is that the tutorial does not show you how to play with the controller, BUT, it is pretty easy to guess AND you can look at your key bind options in the main menu and customize them the way you want (the only controller key I had to set that it needed was lock-on, which I set to left D-pad).Overall, this is an amazing game that feels easy to get in to, but hard to master. I would definitely suggest this game to everyone, especially those looking for games like Star Citizen.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Star conflict is a MMO, action and is also a free to play, which is always a good thing. The game is base in the near future, in which there are three factions; Empire, Federation and Jericho, which all have Interceptor, Fighter and Frigate classed ships.The game is fun, but for those seeking a realist space simulator, don't bother with this game. It isn't anything close to simulator. But for those looking for a game, which is fun and easy to play, then look no further.Since the game is Free to Play, it is to be expected that this game would have mini-transactions and DLC, which in this case, it does. The DLC ships and the in-game "licences" doesn't make much a difference, but I just helps you get more in-game-credits. Also, the Dev's inplemented a Achievement-ish bonuses which allow you to get the premium credits, but it is rare.In conclusion, I find this game highly enteraining and easy to play. Also, the game isn't strictly a "Pay-to-Win" which is always good, in which the game gives you, occasionally, premium credits. I would highly recommend the game to anyone looking for a simple, easy, fun and free game to waste your time in.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Very suprised with how well this game turned out, did not expect to like it as much as I do. If you are a fan of world of tanks, but like the sci-fi, space worlds this may be a game for you. PvE, is a good aspect, open world is, well there, but thats about it, but the PvP is where this game shines for me. The battles can be pretty spectacular, and can get you on the edge of your seat.PvE, is pretty good, and can be very fun, but if your expecting a solo experience, its not in this game. Everything you do is party based, even the open world flying. In that I mean the npc's you face in open world are very OP, if you are not in a rank 6 ship at the very least you will not survive an incounter with multiple npc's.Open world flight pretty much is there just for the purpose of having some daily missions for people to do. Its all pretty much fly here, get this thing, or kill that person, type thing. So its there, but not something this game is for. This game is in its core meant for the pvp, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												I feel as if I've played this game enough to finally write a review. I downloaded this game back in it's beta, and I was really impressed by it. Not only was the game fun, but the aspects of the game as a whole were a new thing entirely. This was the first game in which I've experience true 3-D. What I mean by this is that there is no up and down on the map. Sure you may start faceing a certain way, but unlike games such as Battlefront 2 (first space battle game that I thought of), you can face your ship any which way. The controls are easy to use and understand. The maps big, detailed, and contain various interesting environments. Their a plenty of ships to chose from from three different factions. Different classes of ships have different special abilities. And you can customize your ship's loadout, getting more options as the game progresses. A couple of negatives to the game follow:In the free roam aspect, the goals and objectives are sometimes unclear as to where to go and the map is very big and easy to get lost in.The customization of your ship is limited to it's modules and weapons, with the option to use "standards" for paint schemes and emblems.It seems to me that despite your amount of kills, deaths, captures, whatever, the game will give you more xp if you are on the winning team.Sometimes the matchmaking will put you into games in which the other team has  better ships by a few ranks, this is because the tiers for matchmaking contain multiple levels of ships. For instance, tier two contains ranks 4-9. Despite all of this, the game is very fun and addicting. At one point I had stopped playing back in the beta, but I got back into it due to the enjoyment of grinding even if only for that one double xp game per day. This game has a similar appeal as War Thunder which is made by the same company who made this game. The game is overall very fun and has the grind appeal as well as the enjoyment I find in every game, even if we lose. I definately recommend this game. I can't wait to see what more will be added. Oh, and did I mention it's free to play! Don't worry, paying doesn't seem to help players too much, except for the increased xp gain. 8.75/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												TLDR: I recommend this one as a short term title. Install it and play if for a week or two when everything else you've got feels like the same 'ole. Great fun. But don't plan to stay for the long run unless you're into grinding or willing to cough up some real life cash.First of all, this is not a Space Sim as the description says. It's a session based action shooter, in line with World of Tanks or War Thunder with a control scheme from Freelancer. It also features cooperative scenarios and a open world sandbox mode.It's initially a fun and great looking game. It feels polished and bug free which is great. But the fun will not last.The game has you flying many ships in tiers of level 1-15, and level 1-3 is awesome. You'll get plenty of rewards, can easliy upgrade and can find fun matches both in PvP and PvE scenarios. But as soon as you equip a level 4+ ship it's like hitting a wall.You see, the scenarios are hosted in different difficulties as lvl 1-3, or 4-9 and later on 10-15. That means that if you equip a lv 4 ship you'll enter everything in the 2nd difficulty bracket. Unforutnally, that bracket seem balanced for lvl 9 ships. You will get your behind handed to you, over and over again, unless you're joined by some lvl 9 veterans to help you out. This is also an issue in PvP becaue of the major difference in ships between level 4 to 9, while there was very little between 1-3.Open world opens up at lvl 6 and it took me 5 days of playing to get there, This something that should be mentioned on the store page, that you have to unlock the sandbox mode. This was the gamemode I was mostly looking for.After the initial tutorial missions (which may send you into a open PvP zone where high end players may wait for new noob pray) the difficuly ramps up fast here too. In my lvl 6 I'm just a tad stronger than the avarage NPC's. The problem is that they roam in packs of 3-5. You can kill one, but that's when you have to break off (which only a few ships can with their abilities) or you're toast. I had big hopes for this mode, but sadly it's dull and boring.So the only thing to do is grind ... grind money to buy new ships, grind xp (synergy as they call it) to unlock new ships, grind vouchers (other types of currencies to upgrade weapons and modules), and the grind is a tedious one. The scenarios and maps are few both in PvE and PvP adding futher to the chore. Vouchers are the worst. You can of course get all of these things in a jiffy, as long as you're willing to open your wallet. So what about just staying in lvl 1-3? The fun part? Well, you're kicked out of the kindergarden after 150 matches and forced inte 4+ world. If you're still stuck with 1-3 ships by then, well, you're not going to have fun.As of this moment the game is a great title for a week or so, but expect it to become repetative and grindy real soon. I'll still recommend it since it's free after all , and because I had a blast the first days of playing. Enjoy it untill you reach the difficulty/grind/paywall.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												   Overall, I find Star Conflict a very enjoyable game. The ability to fly through the stars killing things and making money is something I really like. However, the matchmaker has been very slow recently. I'm not sure if it's due to maintenance, an error, or something else, but it's been slow. On PvP mode I can't even get into a match, but strangely I can get into PvE matches, albeit slowly.    In summary, Star Conflict is a fun game, but the fact that the matchmaker has been incredibly slow for me and the fact that I can't play PvP currently certainly sours my experience, so it definitely needs to be fixed.  I do recommend the game though because it is quite fun, but remember that the matchmaker is kind of a crap-shoot currently, so you may want to look elsewhere for the time being.

												Star Conflict is an INCREDIBLE GAME. The graphics are amazing, and when I saw that they launch the game on the Oculus Rift, I totaly freaked out. Beleive it or not, this game is still on beta, as well. To the creators of the game: The only problems are that it could have a Campaign and could have more gamemodes (a good gamemode could be not a destroying, or conquering, but racing, if you think it's a good idea). Another idea is that there could be some kind of "Offline Mode", where you could play normal game modes but with bot players, and also you could select there difficulty, ship rank, and more, if you like.And for the players: If you are thinking about getting the game, go ahead. You have my blessing.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												I feel as if I've played this game enough to finally write a review. I downloaded this game back in it's beta, and I was really impressed by it. Not only was the game fun, but the aspects of the game as a whole were a new thing entirely. This was the first game in which I've experience true 3-D. What I mean by this is that there is no up and down on the map. Sure you may start faceing a certain way, but unlike games such as Battlefront 2 (first space battle game that I thought of), you can face your ship any which way. The controls are easy to use and understand. The maps big, detailed, and contain various interesting environments. Their a plenty of ships to chose from from three different factions. Different classes of ships have different special abilities. And you can customize your ship's loadout, getting more options as the game progresses. A couple of negatives to the game follow:In the free roam aspect, the goals and objectives are sometimes unclear as to where to go and the map is very big and easy to get lost in.The customization of your ship is limited to it's modules and weapons, with the option to use "standards" for paint schemes and emblems.It seems to me that despite your amount of kills, deaths, captures, whatever, the game will give you more xp if you are on the winning team.Sometimes the matchmaking will put you into games in which the other team has  better ships by a few ranks, this is because the tiers for matchmaking contain multiple levels of ships. For instance, tier two contains ranks 4-9. Despite all of this, the game is very fun and addicting. At one point I had stopped playing back in the beta, but I got back into it due to the enjoyment of grinding even if only for that one double xp game per day. This game has a similar appeal as War Thunder which is made by the same company who made this game. The game is overall very fun and has the grind appeal as well as the enjoyment I find in every game, even if we lose. I definately recommend this game. I can't wait to see what more will be added. Oh, and did I mention it's free to play! Don't worry, paying doesn't seem to help players too much, except for the increased xp gain. 8.75/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												   Overall, I find Star Conflict a very enjoyable game. The ability to fly through the stars killing things and making money is something I really like. However, the matchmaker has been very slow recently. I'm not sure if it's due to maintenance, an error, or something else, but it's been slow. On PvP mode I can't even get into a match, but strangely I can get into PvE matches, albeit slowly.    In summary, Star Conflict is a fun game, but the fact that the matchmaker has been incredibly slow for me and the fact that I can't play PvP currently certainly sours my experience, so it definitely needs to be fixed.  I do recommend the game though because it is quite fun, but remember that the matchmaker is kind of a crap-shoot currently, so you may want to look elsewhere for the time being.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Exciting and fast-paced space game. I've just got to tier 3 without paying a penny - don't see what everybody is complaining about. Weapon balancing has been much better recently - I left for a while because I was getting destroyed by disintegrators and coil mortars all the time, but lots of balancing happened, and it has worked out well.The graphics are excellent, but on very low settings, it can look bad, as you would expect. Most gamers out there won't have any trouble being able to run this game.Never noticed the voiceovers being bad or anything. Come to think about it, they do sound a little lifeless - I thought it was for effect.Loving the corporation and faction system, but I'm a little confused when enemies from a previous match are now on my team. I don't know why that happens, but it doesn't matter much.This game is about playing a role in the team. The points and synergy system are about how effective you are in the team. As a frigate, you can get more points by not firing a single shot than by killing everything in sight.Generally, a pretty good game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												TLDR: I recommend this one as a short term title. Install it and play if for a week or two when everything else you've got feels like the same 'ole. Great fun. But don't plan to stay for the long run unless you're into grinding or willing to cough up some real life cash.First of all, this is not a Space Sim as the description says. It's a session based action shooter, in line with World of Tanks or War Thunder with a control scheme from Freelancer. It also features cooperative scenarios and a open world sandbox mode.It's initially a fun and great looking game. It feels polished and bug free which is great. But the fun will not last.The game has you flying many ships in tiers of level 1-15, and level 1-3 is awesome. You'll get plenty of rewards, can easliy upgrade and can find fun matches both in PvP and PvE scenarios. But as soon as you equip a level 4+ ship it's like hitting a wall.You see, the scenarios are hosted in different difficulties as lvl 1-3, or 4-9 and later on 10-15. That means that if you equip a lv 4 ship you'll enter everything in the 2nd difficulty bracket. Unforutnally, that bracket seem balanced for lvl 9 ships. You will get your behind handed to you, over and over again, unless you're joined by some lvl 9 veterans to help you out. This is also an issue in PvP becaue of the major difference in ships between level 4 to 9, while there was very little between 1-3.Open world opens up at lvl 6 and it took me 5 days of playing to get there, This something that should be mentioned on the store page, that you have to unlock the sandbox mode. This was the gamemode I was mostly looking for.After the initial tutorial missions (which may send you into a open PvP zone where high end players may wait for new noob pray) the difficuly ramps up fast here too. In my lvl 6 I'm just a tad stronger than the avarage NPC's. The problem is that they roam in packs of 3-5. You can kill one, but that's when you have to break off (which only a few ships can with their abilities) or you're toast. I had big hopes for this mode, but sadly it's dull and boring.So the only thing to do is grind ... grind money to buy new ships, grind xp (synergy as they call it) to unlock new ships, grind vouchers (other types of currencies to upgrade weapons and modules), and the grind is a tedious one. The scenarios and maps are few both in PvE and PvP adding futher to the chore. Vouchers are the worst. You can of course get all of these things in a jiffy, as long as you're willing to open your wallet. So what about just staying in lvl 1-3? The fun part? Well, you're kicked out of the kindergarden after 150 matches and forced inte 4+ world. If you're still stuck with 1-3 ships by then, well, you're not going to have fun.As of this moment the game is a great title for a week or so, but expect it to become repetative and grindy real soon. I'll still recommend it since it's free after all , and because I had a blast the first days of playing. Enjoy it untill you reach the difficulty/grind/paywall.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I have to say, this is one of the best fast pased ship combat simulator next to freelancer.  The only problems I see are when you alt tab, you can't chat, if you try you seem to have a interface glitch, and the monotization scheme is a bit annoying. You shouldn't have to replenish ammo using Real Life Money. Out side of those major glitches there is one more that plagues this game, its that it crashes on windows when you alt tab after each battle. It seems to freeze the script when you do that and breaks some sort of loop or something and then skips over certian blocks of code that is necessary to run the controlls. It runs great on linux though, no interface glitches or anything. It must have been made for that platform and ported over to windows. Glitches aside, it does have territory controll that you can join corperations to take over places on a large map, but the bad thing is that you have to grind levels to get too it. Its a good way to controll trolls to a point. I'm just glad its not a time grind game like some other game that I won't mention due to respect of this one, Aside from all those problems, the price tag of the game which is free is seriously something to consider if you need a break from your regular point A to point B shoot and kill kind of thing. Out side of that I would give this game a 7.0 out of 10.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Good if you like War Thunder and Space games, as it has the plane aspect of War Thunder with the flying around and shooting and the Space aspect as it is set in space. The things that make Star Conflict different from War Thunder is the different classes and abilities and factions. I will give a brief run down on the classes and factions. The classes fall into 3 major catagories and alot of sub-classes. The 3 main classes that you will encounter is the Interceptor class; which is designed for speed and maneuvelbility, the Fighter class; which is a class that is a good alrounder, and the Frigates; which is designed for Powerful cannons and strong armour. There are also 3 factions that holds all 3 main classes of ships. The 3 factions are: Empire, Federation and Jericho and if you want to go to the back stories, follow this link --> https://star-conflict.com/en/game/storyline <--. There are 15 ranks not including ships that need to be Manufactured. Each rank has differnet ships per rank and the Crew and Workshop options only occur for when you get a rank 4 and rank 6 ship for any factions. There are 2 gamemodes in Star Conflict that are PvP and PvE. PvP is a head to head combat style gamemode for where the pplayer will be given certain tasks, depending on the mission, to either capture beacons, kill the enemy etc. Then there is PvE, which is where the player fights bots throughout missions to receive points. Then there is Syntax Points wihch is what the player needs to upgrade their ships to go to the next rank. And that is a brief run-down on Star Conflict

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I have to say, this is one of the best fast pased ship combat simulator next to freelancer.  The only problems I see are when you alt tab, you can't chat, if you try you seem to have a interface glitch, and the monotization scheme is a bit annoying. You shouldn't have to replenish ammo using Real Life Money. Out side of those major glitches there is one more that plagues this game, its that it crashes on windows when you alt tab after each battle. It seems to freeze the script when you do that and breaks some sort of loop or something and then skips over certian blocks of code that is necessary to run the controlls. It runs great on linux though, no interface glitches or anything. It must have been made for that platform and ported over to windows. Glitches aside, it does have territory controll that you can join corperations to take over places on a large map, but the bad thing is that you have to grind levels to get too it. Its a good way to controll trolls to a point. I'm just glad its not a time grind game like some other game that I won't mention due to respect of this one, Aside from all those problems, the price tag of the game which is free is seriously something to consider if you need a break from your regular point A to point B shoot and kill kind of thing. Out side of that I would give this game a 7.0 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												Looking for naval space combat? This is the game for you!.Star conflict is about ships, upgrades, gathering resources, crafting (On later levels), missions, PvE and PvP and a kind of hybrid version of both of those depending on the matchmaking system.If you are looking for lore, there is virtually none in this game. Battle in space and make your own adventure.The controls are intuitive. There are 3 factions with their own ships; from a sniper to medic, ships that give various buffs, or the tank, the fast and agile ones, there is a ship for every playstyle with their pro and cons.This game is free to play, as long as you are willing to grind, and with some luck you will be able to get virtually everything. Stuff for real money does not give a player any advantage on other players but it helps speeding things up and it supports the game. There are also plenty of aestethic items, colors & more.Worth trying out.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Now to start of this review i'd like to say, i really like this game, and i find it really fun but there are some flaws in this game i would like to adress:First of all, this game is a pay to win game. And i know that there are many games out there like this, but the fact that you have to pay to get the good things in this game, it pisses me off. People with membership or premium or people which actually spend money on this game get all the good stuff, while the free to play have to earn their coins etc.This is not the main point, the main point is that since i have played this game i have experienced so many bugs. The major bug i would like to adress is that when i want to play a good game, i cant becuase im often waiting 5 minutes, whith just one other person! And to fix this problem i have to leave the squad (and my friend too) then re-invite him, then engage, and maybe then we might get a game and this will not always work. There are plenty of other bugs but this is my main bug and it really, really, really, pisses me off.Unfortunately i will have to not recommend this game, so that i get the attention  of the developers so they can fix this damn bug. Like i said i love this game and the gameplay, and the graphics are beautiful, but unless they fix this bug, i wont be happy.

												World of Tanks in space. Generally it plays brilliantly and the rounds are punchy but grossly unvaried, the longevity of this game comes from unlocking better ships and weapons through ongoing play. However, the game title should be Star ConArtist as unless you are a loner that likes to salivate over different types and sizes of spaceship this 'Free to Play' game isn't for you. The developers have fallen into the same trap as WoT and restricted the teamsize to 2 players unless you fork out REAL LIFE MONEY which is a massive shortcoming. Microtransactions I can live with, pay to win I can live with. Restricting who you can play with - No thanks and goodnight!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												I see that a lot of people are rating the game badly, I have played a lot at Star conflict and I still love it, the gameplay is really good, the graphism are good for a F2P, the game has many game mode (chosen randomly, depend if you want a PVE or PVP battle, they did that to reduce queue time). Then the game is quite extreme on the type of ship, you have a tank ship? they'll need 2 people to take you down! You play as an interceptor? you'll die very quicly but you'll go so fast they won't touch you, it may sound bad, but this make each person and ship important in a battle: try to win a battle if the ennemy team has an enginner and you don't. I don't play often, but I truly enjoy it. There is also an open world mode! This hyped the whole community but in lv1 one zone they though that puting some ennemies that can't be killed by a T7 ship was a good idea. The game won't let you buy your ship and weapon easly, but they made some dayly mission for the open world gamemode so you can get money a bit faster. Most of people don't stay on this game so long, you must know that if you are bad at this game, you'll probably uninstall and leave a bad review, but to become good you need to take the ship type that you like, I personaly was bad at this game at start and then I started playing as an special operation interceptor and now I can do some PVP battle without dying once.I saw many people talking about the synergie stuff, it's globaly the XP of your ship, when you reach a certain level you can buy the next one, but if you reach the max level, you'll get 1% of XP boost forever. Sound ridiculous no? but you must know that the first ships don't take that much synergy to lv up the ship, so you can do that with the free synergy (a pourcent of the total synergy winned in a battle can be used on all ship for free). You'll quickly get a 10% boost if you do that, it help thrust me. So before you play, give a fair test to the game, don't play like 20 minute like those idiots at least make sure you tryed all class ship (until T3 ship are really cheap so you can test them without wasting too much money).

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												I'm not certain why so many people are complaining so vehemently against the grinding system in place with Star Conflict. As expected with any F2P, yes, there is a grind involved to unlocking new equipment and ships. But to suggest it's so outlandish that it's "ONE HUGE GRIND," I couldn't disagree more. In my experience, gaining reputation / ships / equipment works well, so long as you play smart. A fantastic game with NO LOAD TIMES, despite the region you're queued in.Pros-Dogfighting is engaging and rewarding-Game SHINES when you begin to play with friends / coordinate attacks-Despite the grind, it's not as egregious as several reviews claim-Excellent visuals with very little demand on graphics cards-Several well-designed ship classes-Several fun game modes with a Free Roaming mode in the works-Achievements for killing / helping Devs, who play fairly often-Not P2WCons-Rough learning curve as you progress through each tier-Gear is often not interchangable between ships that you'd assumed would-Unless in groups, relying on pugs to play objectives in very wishful thinking-Coolest ships are only accessible with actual cash. More of an aesthetic complaint than anything else.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												To start from scratch, Star Conflict is a multiplayer game in which you get the chance to pilot a space ship, flying through the beautiful maps in high definition to fight against various warring groups, with your many options of lasers, blasters and more. To me, it’s more like a simulation than a game, with it’s realistic and futuristic feel. You can install a lot of different tools to your ship, included in these options, is the gun jammer, cloaking, shrapnel mines, shields and many others.ships_systems_pic_a_engThink StarWars, remember all those space hosted star fighter battles? “Raise the shields Artoo!” Well that’s similar to what you’ll experience in this game.scrn_may25_01The basic goal is to not blow up, but you already knew that. It’s how not to be blown up you need to know. Simple. Depending on the ship you’ve acquired, the shields will differ in strength, as well as the guns. Two bars populate the space around you ship (the game is not in the first person yet), one will be the shields, the other… well… i’m not sure what to call it, but when receiving damage from either collision or being shot, you will notice the shield bar drain slightly (unless you get hit with a “one shot kill” blaster, in which case you wouldn’t really see anything accept the re-spawning screen). When that bar is diminished to the max (rendered empty), then the second bar will begin to diminish. The second bar is basically your ships damage status, although, it drains much faster than the shield. After this bar is gone, you’ve blown up.scrn_may25_05This scenario would seem pretty lame… if it wasn’t for the awesome graphics! explosionIn Game Look at all the colors! The graphics are another reason that this game is realistic. I’ve found myself ducking out of the way of a well aimed gun bolt a few times, or flinching when a ship fly’s too close. 1 (22)_1Okay, i’m going to lay off on the screenshots, but iv’e made my point.There are three types of battles, beacon capture (dubbed “Bacon Capture” by many pilots), combat reconnaissance and EMP bomb. Chief among these is beacon capture. In this game, your goal is to capture the beacon (DUH!), and the longer a beacon is captured, the more points the team gets. If a team is being completely dominated, with no beacons in possession, then their points will lower. the first team to hit zero losses. Also, if a beacon is occupied for a certain amount of time, drones start to spawn around it, shooting at any opposing ship within 2000 meters.scrn_may25_03Which begins another point i’d like to make, depending on the gun capability of a ship, there is a certain range at which a weapon can reach. Most beginning guns will hit anything within about 3000 meters. An HUD display will surround all opposing and friendly ships whether to far to see or close enough to crash into, giving stats of distance, direction and other useful information. The direction display will show a circle that moves away from the ship in order for you to have an easier ability to track it’s movements, it helps when your firing at a moving target. All you have to do is point your cursor (also a circle, with a limited amount of movement depending on the ship. It allows the user to steer and target.) into the tracker and shoot. As for range, if the distance between you and your opponent is adequately matched to your gun , then the HUD will change color. This display is especially useful if your hunting the captain in combat recon, or trying to intercept a ship from acquiring a beacon or bomb.All this sounds really fun, and it is. But to play any of these games, you must join them first.The story line of Star Conflict is based off of a battle between three different groups, Jericho, Federation and Empire. When creating an account, or starting the game, you must first choose which group to follow and fight for. Each has it’s own selection of gear, abilities and ships. You will go through a sort of tutorial, with missions. To keep the game interesting, missions continue to be available even after the tutorial ends, and you can get new ones from signing contracts. You can also buy different ships and guns, to help in your battles.To enter a battle, you must press a button at the bottom of your screen, labeled “Launch”. This will give you the option of, PvP or PvE. There are two ways to join a PvP.A map showing a hexagon shaped territory, in which you can choose a specific game.A button that automatically finds a game.To join a specific game using the map function, you have to be with a corporation, costing real money. So normally, i’d choose the second option. This puts you into a small tab that counts how long you’ve been waiting, and gives an estimate on when the next match will begin. PvE also does this, because in both games, you must have a minimum amount of ships to join you. The longest wait time will be five minutes, which is a huge damper when your ready for action and have to just sit there and stare at a clock. The average time you’ll have to wait depends on the amount players that are active. I’ve only seen up to about three minutes of waiting, but even for such a short time it can get pretty mind numbing.Once the game find a spot for you, it will show a “Triangular” text on the wait tab and lock all hanger options. Then it starts the game, showing you a player list of both teams, and the rank that the match is set to. The rank is determined by your type of ship and it’s capability. The same display shows up when your respawning, backed by a background of the map with small icons that represent the positions of all the ships. Sometimes, it will even show the shooting lanes.The average game will last will last a pretty long time, making up for the grueling wait.Another issue that keeps recurring in both my mind and the Star Conflict community is the view point. Currently, when flying a ship, you will see from a third person view. Many players (including me) would really like to see this game from the first person, but the response looks something like this:“the suggestion for a cockpit view has already been forwarded, but at the moment a cockpit view would not be very effective.Due to the limited view you would have a disadvantage compared to 3rd person pilots./closed.”and: “It is planned, but the priority for this is very low at the moment because the cockpit view would be less efficient in battle.“So I guess it’s in progress.In conclusion, Star Conflict is a great game, with fantastic graphics, realistic piloting scenarios, fun and competitive games and a good story line (my friends and I often argue about which group is dominant). Although, there are a couple problems I have with it, like the wait time, 3rd person view, foul language in the intercom (can easily be shut off in the options) and lack of variety which causes the game to get dull after a while. There are many disadvantages and advantages, but the problems fall far short of making Star Conflict unplayable, and the good parts dominate intensely.http://jumocreations.wordpress.com/2014/04/01/star-conflict/
